children.definition: Dim. of πατήρ, papa, daddy, Ar. V. 986, Xenarch. 4.15, Theophil. 4.
= Lat. patricius, Plb. 10.4.2, D.H. 2.8, 10, 48, etc.
= patricius calceus, Plu. Tranq. 2.470c (but κάλτιος πα<τρι>κιᾶτος Edict.Diocl. 9.7 (pl.).

children.label: II
children.definition: POxy. 1206.1 (iv A. D.), Procop. Pers. 1.8, Just. Nov. 38 tit., etc. :—fem. πατρικία, PKlein.Form. 1091 (vi A.D.), etc.
patriciate, Prisc.p.343 D., Just. Nov. 38 Praef. 3.

derived from oneʼs fathers, hereditary, νόμοι Cratin. 116 ; ἀρίς Call.Com. 16 ; φίλος Ar. Av. 142 ; φίλοι OGI 227.9 ( Didyma, iii B. C.) ; βασιλεῖαι Th. 1.13, Arist. Pol. 1285a19 ; ἁμαρτεῖν τοῦ π. τύπου Democr. 228 ; αἱ π. ἀρεταί Th. 7.69 ; ξένος And. 2.11, Th. 8.6 ; ἐχθρός Lys. 14.40 ; φύσει τῆς πρὸς ὑμᾶς ἔχθρας αὐτοῖς ὑπαρχούσης πατρικῆς D. 21.49 ; εἰς τὸ π., = by right of inheritance, PTeb. 5.12 (ii B.C.).

data.quote: φύσει τῆς πρὸς ὑμᾶς ἔχθρας αὐτοῖς ὑπαρχούσης πατρικῆς

children.label: II
children.definition: of or belonging to oneʼs father, γᾶρυς S. Ichn. 65 (lyr.) ; ὁ π. λόγος Pl. Sph. 242a ; ἡ π. πρόσταξις Arist. EN 1180a19 ; οἰκονομία π., opp. δεσποτική and γαμική, Id. Pol. 1253b10 ; ἐνευχόμενός σοι τοὺς π. θεούς the gods of your father(s), PCair.Zen. 421.2 (iii B.C.) ; ἡ πατρική (sc. οὐσία) patrimony, E. Ion 1304 ; π. οἰκία PStrassb. 99.4 (ii B.C.) ; τὰ π. AP 11.75 ( Lucill.) ; but τὰ π., also, fatherʼs house, LXX Si. 42.10.

like a father, paternal, π. γὰρ ἀρχὴ βούλεται ἡ βασιλεία εἶναι Arist. EN 1160b26 ; π. καὶ συγγενικὴ αἵρεσις Plb. 31.25.1 ; παρρησία π. Plu. Praec. 2.802f ; π. θεός OGI 418 ( Judaea, i A. D.). Adv., τὰς κολάσεις πατρικῶς ποιεῖσθαι Arist. Pol. 1315a21 ; ὁ θεὸς π. κηδόμενος τοῦ ἀνθρωπείου γένους Plu. Cons.Apoll. 2.117d.

data.quote: π. γὰρ ἀρχὴ βούλεται ἡ βασιλεία εἶναι
ὁ θεὸς π. κηδόμενος τοῦ ἀνθρωπείου γένους

children.definition: ἡ πατρική, = ἡ γενική, the genitive, Choerob. in Theod. 1.111 H.
inherited from a father, Phot.

definition: πάτριος, α, ον, Lyr. and Trag. ; also ος, ον E. Hel. 222, and Att. Com., Prose (exc. And. 3.27), and Inscrr. (so elsewh., SIG 539 A 14 ( Delph., iii B.C.), 558.21 ( Ithaca, iii B.C.), etc.) : ( πατήρ) :—

children.definition: of or belonging to oneʼs father, ἄρουρα Pi. O. 2.14 ; ὄσσα ib. 6.62 ; γῆ S. Ant. 806 (lyr.), E. Med. 651 (lyr.) ; χθών Id. Hel. 222 ; τεύχεα, δώματα, S. Ph. 398 (lyr.), OT 1394.

children.label: II
children.definition: derived from oneʼs fathers, hereditary, οἱ π. θεοί Hdt. 1.172, Sammelb. 6664.5 ( Egypt, ii B.C.), IG 7.2713.51 (i A.D.) ; πάτριος θεά Milet. 7.64 (ii/iii A.D.) ; αἱ π. τελεταί Ar. Ra. 368 ; ἱερά Th. 2.16 ; νόμοι Id. 4.118, Decr. ap. Arist. Ath. 29.3, X. HG 2.3.2 ; θυσίαι Isoc. 10.63, IG 2(2).780, etc.; π. πολιτεία Thrasym. 1, Arist. Ath. 34.3, D.S. 14.3, etc.; π. ἀρχαί X. Cyr. 1.1.4, cf. Arist. Pol. 1285a24, 33 ; αἱ τιμαὶ αἱ π. Isoc. 9.32 ; π. καὶ ἀρχαῖα νόμιμα Pl. Lg. 793b ; τὸν π. ὅρκον PPetr. 3p.163 (iii B.C.) ; -ωτέρα ἡγεμονία more ancient, Isoc. 4.37 ; πάτριόν ἐστιν (sc. αὐτοῖς) it is an hereditary custom [among them], Ar. Ec. 778, cf. Th. 1.123, X. HG 7.1.3, SIG 695.16 ( Magn. Mae., ii B.C.), etc.; οὐ γὰρ π. τᾷ Σπάρτᾳ Tyrt. 15.6 ; οὐκ ἦν ταῦτα τοῖς τότε Ἀθηναίοις πάτρια D. 18.203, cf. Pl. Hp.Ma. 284b ; τάδε π. Ὀλβιοπολίταις καὶ Μιλησίοις, in a treaty, SIG 286.1 (iv B.C.) ; τὰ πάτρια ancestral customs, κατὰ τὰ π. IG 1(2).76.4, Ar. Ach. 1000, Th. 2.2, etc. ; παρὰ τὰ π. Pl. Plt. 296c ; ποιεῖν πρὸς τὴν πόλιν τὰ π. to serve the state as our fathers before us, Isoc. 4.31 : less freq. in sg., τὸ π. παρείς neglecting the inherited constitution, Th. 4.86. Adv., πατρίως Ἰουδαίοις according to the custom of their fathers, J. BJ 1.24.2 ; π. καλούμενον in their native language, ib. 5.2.1, cf. Lyd. Mens. 4.64 ; v. πατρῷος sub fin.

data.quote: οὐκ ἦν ταῦτα τοῖς τότε Ἀθηναίοις πάτρια

children.label: III
children.definition: Subst. πάτριος, ὁ, uncle, BSA 17.240 (Pamphyl.).

definition: πατρίς, ίδος, poet. fem. of πάτριος,

children.definition: of oneʼs fathers, πατρὶς αἶα, ἄρουρα, oneʼs fatherland, country, Od. 10.236, 20.193; π. γαῖα 24.322, Hes. Sc. 1, 12, A. Th. 585; γῆ π. S. OT 641, Ar. Th. 859 (paratrag.) ; π. πόλις the city of oneʼs sires, Pi. O. 10(11).36.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., = πάτρα I, Il. 5.213, Od. 4.586, 9.34, Hdt. 3.140, Th. 6.69, etc.; κοινὴ π., i.e. the nether world, Plu. Cons.Apoll. 2.113c : prov., π. γάρ ἐστι πᾶσʼ ἵνʼ ἂν πράττῃ τις εὖ, ubi bene, ibi patria, Ar. Pl. 1151; simply, native town or village, UPZ 9.5 (ii B. C.), Ev.Marc. 6.1, etc. : pl., ἐν ταῖς αὑτῶν π. D. 18.296, cf. 305, Pl. Plt. 308a, Hyp. Epit. 10.
OGI 46.7 ( Halic., iii B.C.), Bull.Soc. royale des lettres de Lund 1928/9iv3 ( Thuria, ii B.C.).

definition: πατριώτης, ου, Dor. -τας, ὁ, voc. -ῶτα Nico 1 : ( πάτριος) :—

children.definition: fellow-countryman : prop. of barbarians who had only a common πατρίς, πολῖται being used of Greeks who had a common πόλις, Poll. 3.54, Hsch., Phot.: hence μήτε πατριώτας ἀλλήλων εἶναι τοὺς μέλλοντας ῥᾷον δουλεύσειν Pl. Lg. 777c ; τοῖσι Λυκούργου π., Lycurgus being satirized as an Egyptian, Pherecr. 11, cf. Alex. 326 ; also ἵπποι π., = ἐγχώριοι, X. Cyr. 2.2.26 : metaph., of Mt. Cithaeron, π. Οἰδίπου S. OT 1091 (lyr.); π. θεός, of Dionysus, Plu. QConv. 2.671c ; π. ἐστί μοι.—Ans. ἐλάνθανες ἄρα βάρβαρος ὤν Luc. Sol. 5 ; cf. πατριῶτις.

data.quote: μήτε πατριώτας ἀλλήλων εἶναι τοὺς μέλλοντας ῥᾷον δουλεύσειν

children.label: II
children.definition: Iamb. VP 5.21.

children.label: III
children.definition: member of a πατριά II.1, IG 4.757 B12 ( Troezen), Michel 995 B 4 ( Delph., v B. C.).
of or belonging to a πατριώτης or πατριά, ἀργύριον BCH 50.16 ( Delph., iv B. C.); τεμένη Arist. Oec. 1346b15 ; ἱερά Dicaearch. Hist. 9.

definition: πατριῶτις, ιδος, fem. of πατριώτης, π. γῆ,

children.definition: E. Heracl. 755 (lyr.); π. στολή oneʼs own countryʼs dress, said by a barbarian, Luc. Scyth. 3.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἄρτεμις π. IG 5(1).602.11 ( Sparta).
hereditary senator, IG 12(5).141.7 ( Paros), Jul. Ep. 54, PLond. 3.971.7 (iv A. D.).
ancestral, Plu. QConv. 2.730e (s.v.l.).
begotten of the father, Orac. ap. Dam. Pr. 206.
hereditary member of the γερουσία, Ephes. 2.20 iii 4 (ii A. D.).
taught by a father, Sch.ad Tz. H. 7.959 in An. Ox. 3.370.
given by a father, Luc. Trag. 268.

from or after a father, π. ἐκ γενεῆς ὀνομάζων naming him and giving his fatherʼs name, Il. 10.68, cf. Hdt. 3.1, Th. 7.69, Pl. Ly. 204e; τὸ μὲν π. ἐκ Διὸς εὔχονται on the fatherʼs side, Pi. O. 7.23; εἴπερ . . ἔστʼ ἐμὸς τὰ π. S. Aj. 547, cf. OC 215 (lyr.); ἐν στήλῃ π. ἀναγραφῆναι to have oneʼs name inscribed on a tablet with the addition of oneʼs fatherʼs name, Hdt. 6.14, cf. 8.90; γράψαι τοὔνομα π. καὶ φυλῆς καὶ δήμου to write oneʼs name adding that of oneʼs father, tribe, and township, Pl. Lg. 753c, cf. OGI 222.44 ( Clazomenae, iii B. C.), Milet. 3 No.152.93 (ii B. C.), etc.; π. καὶ πατρίδος PRev.Laws 7.3 (iii B. C.).
coming from, sent by oneʼs father, ἀνάγκα π., imposed by Zeus, Pi. O. 3.28; π. ἀλάστωρ A. Ag. 1507 (lyr.) ; π. εὐκταία φάτις a fatherʼs curse, Id. Th. 841 (lyr.).
from the time of oneʼs fathers, π. φίλοι τοῦ δήμου IG 2(2).237.8.
fatherʼs sister, IG 42(1).483 (Epid.), Q.S. 10.58.
fatherʼs brother, Il. 21.469, Od. 6.330, 13.342, Hes. Th. 501.

Patroclus, Hom., who has also obl. cases from Πατροκλῆς ( -κλέης), viz. gen. Πατροκλῆος, acc. Πατροκλῆα, voc. Πατρόκλεες : gen. pl. Πατρόκλων Ar. Ra. 1041 : nom. Πατροκλῆς, Theoc. 15.140 : Πατρόκλεια, ἡ, name of the sixteenth book of the Iliad, Ael. VH 13.14, Eust. 1041.19.
taking care of her father, Nonn. D. 26.103.
murder oneʼs father, A. Ch. 909, Luc. Tyr. 1.
murder of a father, parricide, Hipparch. ap. Stob. 4.44.81, Plu. Rom. 22, Iamb. VP 17.78 (pl.).
parricidium, Gloss.

murdering oneʼs father, parricidal, A. Th. 752 (lyr.), etc.; π. δίκη trial for parricide, S. Fr. 696; π. μίασμα the foul slayer of my father, A. Ch. 1028 : also in later Prose, Ph. 2.73, Porph. Abst. 3.19.

children.label: II
children.definition: χεὶρ π. a fatherʼs murdering hand, E. IT 1083.
neglect of oneʼs father, PMasp. 97 B 51 (vi A. D.).
parricide, AP 11.348 ( Antiphan.).

definition: πατρολοός, ὁ, = foreg., PMasp. 353.7 (vi A. D.).

children.definition: motherʼs father, Luc. Alex. 58.
grandmother, Lyc. 502.
one whose father was a μύστης, hereditary μύστης, IGRom. 4.1393 ( Smyrna).
hold office of πατρονόμος, IG 5(1).18 B 4 ( Sparta).

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., to be under a patriarchal government, Pl. Lg. 680e, Plu. Dio 10.
paternal government, Luc. Dem.Enc. 12.

children.label: II
children.definition: office of πατρονόμος, at Sparta, IG 5(1).311, al.; ἡ θεοῦ Λυκούργου π. ib. 541.17.
pertaining to fatherly rule : ἡ -κή (sc. ἀρχή or τροφή) the rule or nurture of a father, Pl. Lg. 927e.
member of the council instituted by Cleomenes III at Sparta, IG 5(1).32, al., Plu. An seni 2.795f, Paus. 2.9.1, Philostr. VA 4.32 ; ἐπὶ π. σεῶ Λυκούργω IG 5 (1).311.
ancestral tradition, PMasp. 151.183 (vi A. D.).

handed down from oneʼs fathers, inherited, ἡ μικρὰ καὶ π. οὐσία D.H. 5.48 ; ἡ π. ἡγεμονία D.S. 17.4 ; ἀναστροφή 1 Ep.Pet. 1.18 ; Ζεύς OGI 331.49 ( Pergam., ii B. C.), παρέχεσθαι π. τὰν εὔνοιαν CIG 2134b4 (prob.), cf. IG 12 (5).860.4 ( Tenos).
fatherʼs father, Pi. P. 9.82, N. 6.16, A.R. 1.170, IG 12(5).303 ( Paros) ; as title of gods, π. Σάραπις Sammelb. 5802.4 (i A. D.), cf. 1570.4 (i B. C.).
adopted as a father, Supp.Epigr. 6.77 ( Galatia, iii A. D., in form - πόητος), Klio 24.61 (Galatia, written - φοίητος—.

definition: πατρόπολις, εως, ἡ, coined by Antiph. 220 in the line μητρόπολίς ἐστιν οὐχὶ π. πόλις.

children.definition: parricide, Suid.
reft of father, fatherless, A. Ch. 253.
act of beating oneʼs father, Corp.Herm. 9.3 (pl.).
one who beats his father, Is. Fr. 166, Ph. 1.135, S.E. M. 2.44, Theon Prog. 13.
beating of oneʼs father, S.E. M. 2.46.

definition: πατρούεος, α, ον, Thess. for πατρώϊος, πατρῷος, IG 9(2).234.4 ( Pharsalus, iii B. C.).

children.definition: heiress, Hdt. 6.57 codd. (fort. πατρῳοῦχος, cf. πατρωϊῶχος).
devouring oneʼs patrimony, spendthrift, Gloss.
murderer of oneʼs father, [ Ὀρέστης] ἔκτανε πατροφονῆα Αἴγισθον . . , ὅ οἱ πατέρα κλυτὸν ἔκτα Od. 1.299, cf. 3.197.

data.quote: Ὀρέστης] ἔκτανε πατροφονῆα Αἴγισθον . . , ὅ οἱ πατέρα κλυτὸν ἔκτα

children.definition: commit parricide, Phld. Sto. 339.10.
slaying a father, χείρ A. Th. 783 (lyr.), μάτηρ E. Or. 193 (lyr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., parricide, Pl. Lg. 869b.
= foreg., S. OT 1441 : fem., τῆς π. μητρός Id. Tr. 1125.
stepfather, CIG 3445 ( Lydia), Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).128, Eust. 560.26 : also πατρυός, Cat.Cod.Astr. 2.174.
Hdn. 1.7.1, Alciphr. 3.14, Them. Or. 5.71b : c. acc. modi, π. τὴν σοφίαν Philostr. VA 6.16 ; τὴν δεινότητα Id. VS 2.9.3.
worshipper of a θεὸς πατρῷος, Schwyzer 137 (Corc.).
Leg.Gort. 7.15, al.
= Lat. patronus, SIG 656.23 (Abdera, found at Teos, ii B. C.), IG 7.83 ( Megara), D.S. 29.27, Plu. Fab. 13, Arr. Epict. 3.9.18, etc. :—fem. πατρώνα, dub. in GDI 2282 (Delph.).

children.label: II
children.definition: uncle, IGRom. 4.621 ( Temenothyrae, iii A. D.).
= Lat. patronatus, D.H. 2.10, Plu. Rom. 13, Paul.Al. L. 3.
to be a patron, GDI 2688.7 ( Delph., i B. C.) :— Pass., D.S. 40.5, PMasp. 151.229 (vi A. D.).
IGRom. 4.170, 171 (Cyzic.).
rights of a patron, PMasp. 29.5 (vi A. D.).
of or for a πάτρων, POxy. 1205.6 (iii A. D.), Just. Nov. 1.4.1, Suid.
patroness, IG 14.1671, Stud.Pont. 3.190, POxy. 478.27 (ii A. D.), etc.
have the patronymic formed, Eust. 13.41.
name taken from oneʼs father, patronymic, as Πηλεΐδης, Ἀτρεΐδης, Eust. 1388.24.
derived from oneʼs fatherʼs name, patronymic, ὄνομα D.H. 3.48, cf. D.T. 634.26, S.E. M. 1.133 ; τύπος A.D. Conj. 248.6 : - κόν, τό, ib. 7.

definition: πατρωνύμιος, ον: τὸ π., as Adv.,

children.definition: by the fatherʼs side, A. Pers. 146 (s.v.l., anap.).
named after his father, Quarterly of Dept. of Antiquities in Palestine 1.155 ( Gaza, iii A. D.).

definition: πατρῷος, α, ον, also ος, ον A. Ag. 210 (lyr.), E. Supp. 1147 (lyr.), etc. ; Ep. and Ion. πατρώϊος, η, ον, the only form used in Hom., Hes., and Hdt.; the former first in Thgn. 888, Pi. P. 4.290, though both use the longer form, Thgn. 521, Pi. P. 4.220 ; Thess. πατρούεος (q.v.) : ( πατήρ) :—

children.definition: of or from oneʼs father, coming or inherited from him, σκῆπτρον, ἔγχος, Il. 2.46, 19.387 ; τέμενος, δῶμα, οἶκος, 20.391, 21.44, Hes. Op. 376 ; ξεῖνος πατρώϊός ἐσσι παλαιός my old hereditary friend, Il. 6.215 ; π. ἑταῖροι Od. 2.254, 17.69 ; γαῖα πατρωΐη oneʼs fatherland, 13.188, 251 ; πατρῴα γῆ Thgn. 888, Pi. P. 4.290, S. El. 67, etc.; π. οὖδας A. Ag. 503 ; ἄστυ S. OT 1450 ; δῶμα, ἑστία, κοῖται, E. Or. 1595, Hec. 22, S. El. 194 (lyr.); πατρώϊα oneʼs fatherʼs goods, patrimony, Od. 17.80, 20.336, 22.61 ; τὰ π. Hdt. 9.26, Ar. Th. 819, Lys. 27.11, v.l. in Arist. Pol. 1303b34 ; τὰ π. χρήματα Ar. Av. 1658 ; θρόνος A. Pr. 230, cf. S. El. 268, etc.; δοῦλοι π. Hdt. 2.1 ; γέρεα Id. 7.104 ; θυσίαι D. Ep. 3.30 codd. ; ἀρχή X. An. 1.7.6 ; π. δόξα hereditary glory, Id. HG 7.5.16 (but πατρῴα καὶ παππῴα δόξα of our fathers and grandfathers, D. 10.73) ; π. οἰκία, κλῆρος, And. 1.62, Pl. Chrm. 157e, Lg. 923d, etc.; οὐσία Anaxandr. 45 ; ἡ εἰρήνη ἡ π. IG 42(1).68.13 ( Epid., iv B. C.) ; ἔχων π. ἡμῶν ὑποθήκην Sammelb. 7339.6 (i A. D.) ; π. θεοί tutelary gods of a family or people, as Apollo at Athens, S. Ph. 933, cf. Pl. Euthd. 302d, Arist. Ath. 55.3, Sammelb. 6262.5 (iii A. D.) ; Zeus among the Dorians, A. Fr. 162.3 ; πρὸς θεῶν π. καὶ μητρῴων X. HG 2.4.21, cf. Th. 7.69 : sg., Berl.Sitzb. 1927.169 ( Cyrene) ; Zeus was the θεὸς π. of Heracles, S. Tr. 288, 753 ; of Orestes, E. El. 671 ; Ζεὺς π. was also the god who protects parents’ rights, Ar. Nu. 1468, Pl. Lg. 881d, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: of or belonging to oneʼs father, μῆλα Od. 12.136 ; π. πρὸς στάθμαν Pi. P. 6.45 ; π. ἄεθλοι imposed by him, ib. 4.220; but π. ἆθλος of him, S. Ant. 856 (lyr.) ; π. γνώμη ib. 640 ; π. φόνοι, πήματα, Id. OC 990, 1196 ; π. χέρες A. Ag. 210 (lyr.), etc.; τὰ πατρώϊα the cause of oneʼs father, opp. τὰ μητρώϊα, Hdt. 3.53.—Gramm. distd. πατρῷος, as expressing patrimonial possession, from πάτριος as expressing hereditary manners, customs, institutions ; v. Ammon. Diff. s.v., AB 297, Suid., etc.—The distn. holds in Att. Prose ; but Hom. and Hdt. use πατρώϊος only, and in all these senses ; so also Trag. [ πάτριος shd. be restored in all passages in Trag. where the 2nd syll. is made short in anap. and lyr., E. Hec. 82, Tr. 162, Ba. 1368, El. 1315, Alc. 249 ; but γῆς ἀπὸ πατρωΐης ends a pentameter in IG 1(2).978.]
stepfather, Cerc. 4.43, Plu. Cleom. 11, Arat. 41, Artem. 3.26, POxy. 1257.2 (iii A. D.).

definition: πάτρως, ὁ, gen. ωος and ω ; dat. πάτρῳ Pi. P. 6.46, Hdt. 6.103, PCair.Zen. 580 (iii B. C.); acc. πάτρωα Stesich. 17, Leg.Gort. 12.29, J. AJ 19.2.1, πάτρων Hdt. 4.76, 9.78 : pl. πάτρωες Eust. 316.15 (but οἱ πάτρω BCH 11.471 ( Lydia)); Cret. acc. pl. πάτρωανς Leg.Gort. 8.44 ; dat. pl. πάτρωσι Dessau ILS 8897 : ( πατήρ) :—

children.definition: fatherʼs brother, uncle, Il.cc.
two-year-old stag or buck, when the horns are still mere pegs or ‘dags’, brocket or pricket, Arist. HA 611a34.
possessor, prob. for πατήρ in Critias 15.4 D., cf. Hsch.

definition: πατώσας (- ώμας cod.) · διατριβούσας, Hsch. παῦ, v. παύω.

children.definition: rest, pause, S. OC 88 ; οὐκ ἐν παύλῃ ἐφαίνετο there seemed to be no end of it, Th. 6.60.

π. νόσου cessation or end of disease, S. Ph. 1329, cf. Hp. Mul. 2.124 ; κακῶν S. Tr. 1255, Plu. Thes. 15 ; μόχθων prob. in B. 9.8 ; παροξυσμοῦ Gal. 10.604 ; παῦλαν ἔχον κινήσεως παῦλαν ἔχει ζωῆς Pl. Phdr. 245c ; ἡδονὴν . . παῦλαν λύπης εἶναι Id. R. 584b ; π. ταῖς γυναιξὶ τοῦ τεκνοῦσθαι Arist. HA 585a35 ; ἡ π. τῆς τεκνοποιίας Id. Pol. 1335a31 ; παῦλάν τινʼ αὐτῶν some means of stopping them, X. An. 5.7.32. (Written παῦλλα Puchstein Epigr.Gr. p.7.)

data.quote: παῦλαν ἔχον κινήσεως παῦλαν ἔχει ζωῆς

definition: παυνί: μικρόν, οἱ δὲ μέγα ἢ ἀγαθόν, Hsch. παῦνις: ἀπόχρεως, Id. παῦνον· μέγα, Id. παυράκις· ὀλιγάκις ἢ οὐδὲν ὅλως, Id. παυρακίς,
παυράς, άδος, poet. fem. of παῦρος, Nic. Th. 210.

children.definition: Hes. Op. 133.
of few words, AP 7.713 ( Antip.).

definition: παῦρος, ον (not found in fem., cf. παυράς),

children.definition: little, small, στήμων Hes. Op. 538 ; π. ἔπος Pi. O. 13.98 ; of Time, short, Hes. Op. 326 ; ζωῆς μέρος Emp. 2.3 ; π. ὕπνος Pi. P. 9.25 (s.v.l.); speedy, τέλος βιότοιο Q.S. 7.613 : neut. as Adv., for a short time, παῦρον ἀνθήσας Lyc. 1429.

few, poet. for ὀλίγος (q.v.) in this sense, Ep., Lyr., and Trag., π. ἄνδρες Thgn. 79 ; π. τινές Pi. O. 10(11).22 ; π. ἀνδρῶν A. Ag. 832 : rare in Prose, as Thphr. HP 8.7.4 ; παῦρα, opp. πολλά, Il. 9.333, cf. Od. 2.241 : with a collect. Subst., π. λαός small in number, Il. 2.675 : Comp. παυρότερος 4.407, 8.56, al., Thgn. 644 : neut. pl. παῦρα as Adv., seldom, Hes. Th. 780, Ar. Pax 764. (Cf. Lat. paucus, Goth. fawai ‘few’.)

definition: παῦς, ὁ, ἡ, in nom. sg.,

children.definition: Griech. Vaseninschr. p.188.
stilling the wind, θυσία A. Ag. 215 (lyr.).
allayer of sorrow, S. Fr. 887 (ubi leg. π. κάκʼ Ἀτρειδᾶν allaying the sorrows of the A.).
ending evils, Sch. Pi. O. 2.1.
projecting collar worn by slaves while grinding corn or kneading bread, to prevent them from eating any of the ἄλφιτα, Ar. Fr. 302, cf. Ael.Dion. Fr. 276 ; also by animals, Suid.
ending pain, Ζεύς S. Fr. 425 (lyr.) ; ἄμπελος E. Ba. 772 ; ὁ π. οἶκος, i.e. the grave, IG 14.2136.
curing sickness, IG 3.900 [IG 2(2).3575].
stopping drowsiness, Ael.Dion. Fr. 277.
ending toil or hardship, c. gen., E. IT 451 (lyr.), Ar. Ra. 1321 (lyr.); παυσιπόνῳ λάθας πόματι Epigr.Gr. 244.10 (Cyzic.).
stopping, ceasing, LXX Je. 31(48).2.
one must stop, put an end to, Pl. R. 391e, Grg. 523d, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: παύομαι) one must cease, Plu. Lib.educ. 2.6c : c. gen., τῆς ὁρμῆς Dexipp. Hist. 26.10 J.
one who stops or relieves, νόσου S. Ph. 1438, cf. El. 304, Alex. 240.9.
fit for ending or relieving, νόσου S. OT 150.

children.label: II
children.definition: παυστήριον, τό, alleviation, Nic. Th. 746 ; τοῦ κακοῦ Ar.Byz.Arg. S. OT 11.
outwork, fence, Hsch.
Orion died, Id.
= foreg. [παυστήριος] I, δίψης EM 543.51.
Isyll. 56.
checking insolence, cj. in A. Fr. 360.
soothing pain, Sch. S. Ph. 44.

παύεσκον Od. 22.315, S. Ant. 963 (lyr.): fut. παύσω Il. 1.207, etc.; Ep. inf. παυσέμεν ( κατα-) 7.36 : aor. ἔπαυσα 15.15, etc., Ep. παῦσα 17.602 : pf. πέπαυκα D. 20.70, Antisth. Od. 10 :— Med. and Pass., Ion. impf. παυέσκετο Il. 24.17 : fut. παύσομαι Od. 2.198, Hdt. 1.56, S. OC 1040, Ph. 1424, E. Med. 93, etc. ; πεπαύσομαι only S. Ant. 91, Tr. 587 (though held to be the true Att. form by Moer. p.293P.); παυσθήσομαι ( v.l. παυθ-) Th. 1.81 ; later παήσομαι ( ἀνα-) Apoc. 14.13 : aor. ἐπαυσάμην Il. 14.260 ; ἐπαύθην, Ep. παύθην, Hes. Th. 533, Th. 5.91 (v.l. παυσθῇ), etc. ; ἐπαύσθην Hdt. 5.94, etc. ; later ἐπάην Choerob. in Theod. 2.141 H. : pf. πέπαυμαι Il. 18.125, A. Pr. 615, Hdt. 1.84, Ar. Pax 29, etc. ( πεπάσθαι is f.l. in Vett.Val. 359.31):

children.label: I
children.definition: make to end,

bring to an end, check, sts. of persons, ἵνα παύσομεν ἄγριον ἄνδρα Il. 21.314, cf. S. Ant. 963 (lyr.), Ar. Eq. 330 ; stop or silence by death, Od. 20.274, S. OT 397 :— Pass. and Med., take oneʼs rest, ἐνὶ κλισίῃ Il. 24.17, cf. Hdt. 9.52, etc.; cease, have done, Il. 8.295, Od. 4.103, etc. ; of one singing or speaking, 17.359, Hdt. 7.8.δʹ: generally, Med. denotes willing, Pass. forced, cessation.

children.label: b
children.definition: make an end of, stop, abate, χόλον, μένος, νεῖκος πολέμοιο, ῥόον, ὀδύνας, etc., Il. 19.67, 1.282, Od. 24.543, 5.451, Il. 16.528, etc. ; μέριμναν Pi. I. 8(7).13 (s. v.l.) ; λύπας ᾠδαῖς π. E. Med. 197 (anap.), etc. ; π. τόξον let the bow rest, Od. 21.279 ; π. τοὺς γάμους S. Ant. 575 ; πόντου σάλον E. El. 1242 ; π. τὸν νόμον annul it, Id. Or. 571 ; π. τὸν λόγον close it, X. Cyr. 8.6.7 ; τυραννίδα καταλύσαντα πεπαυκέναι D. 20.70; π. τείχη raze them, D.C. 69.9 :— Pass., Th. 5.91, etc.

hinder, keep back, or give one rest, from a thing, π. Ἕκτορα μάχης, πόνοιο Ἀχιλῆα, Θάμυριν ἀοιδῆς, Πηνελόπειαν κλαυθμοῖο, Il. 15.15, 21.137, 2.595, Od. 4.801 ; π. τινὰ ἀλκῆς, ἄλης, καμάτοιο, ὀδυνάων, Il. 15.250, Od. 15.342, 5.492, Il. 4.191 ; so π. χεῖρας πολέμοιο 21.294 ; ὀρχηθμοῖο πόδας Od. 23.298 ; π. τινὰ τῆς βοῆς S. El. 798 ; τῆς ὕβρεως Ar. Av. 1259 ; τῆς λυγγός Pl. Smp. 185d ; τῆς ἁμαρτίας καὶ ἀμα θίας Id. Lg. 784c ; τῶν ἐπιθυμιῶν X. Mem. 1.2.5 ; [ τῆς νόσου] IG 42(1).121.71 ( Epid., iv B. C.) ; π. τινὰ τῆς βασιληΐης depose one from being king, Hdt. 1.123 ; τινὰ τῆς ἀρχῆς, τῆς στρατηγίας, X. Cyr. 8.6.3, HG 6.2.13 ; τῆς ἔξω ξυμμαχίας τινάς Th. 3.65 ; also π. τινὰ ἐκ κακῶν S. El. 987 ; τινὰ ἀπὸ παιδαγωγῶν X. Lac. 3.1 ; with acc. unexpressed, αἴ κέ ποθι Ζεὺς . . παύσῃ ὀϊζύος Od. 4.35 ; φάρμαχʼ ἅ κεν παύσῃσι . . ὀδυνάων Il. 4.191 :— Pass. and Med., rest or cease from a thing, πολέμοιο, μάχης, ἔργων, πόνου, γόοιο, κλαυθμοῦ, ὀδυνάων, κλαγγῆς, etc., 21.432, 467, Od. 4.683, 24.384, 9.540, 17.7, 4.812, Il. 2.100, etc. ; τῆς μάχης, τοῦ δρόμου, Hdt. 1.74, 4.124 ; γόων E. Med. 1211 ; τῆς ὀργῆς Lys. 19.6 ; φιλανθρώπου τρόπου A. Pr. 11 ; παύεσθαι ἀρχῆς to be deposed from, or reach the term of, office, Hdt. 1.56, cf. 6.66, IG 1(2).114.46 ; ἐκ μεγάλων ἀχέων παυσαίμεθʼ ἄν Ar. Ra. 1531 (lyr.); ἐκ τρόχων πεπαυμένοι E. Med. 46, cf. El. 1108.

data.quote: αἴ κέ ποθι Ζεὺς . . παύσῃ ὀϊζύος

children.definition: pres. part., stop a person from . . , π. τινὰ ἀριστεύοντα stop him from doing bravely, Il. 11.506 ; τὸν ἄνδρα παῦσον ταῦτα ποιεῦντα Hdt. 5.23 ; γελῶντας ἐχθροὺς π. S. El. 1295 ; παύσω δέ σʼ ὄντʼ ἄπαιδα E. Med. 717 :— Pass. and Med., leave off doing . . , ὅθʼ ὕπνος ἕλοι, παύσαιτό τε νηπιαχεύων when he stopped playing, Il. 22.502, cf. A. Pr. 615, Ag. 1047, Hdt. 1.133, etc.; of things, ἄνεμος μὲν ἐπαύσατο . . θύων Od. 12.400 : the part. is freq. to be supplied, αἷμα, φλόξ, ἄνεμος ἐπαύσατο, the blood stopped [flowing], the fire [burning], the wind [blowing], Il. 11.267, 23.228, Od. 12.168, etc. ; so Ῥοδώπιος πέρι πέπαυμαι (sc. λέγων) Hdt. 2.135, cf. 7.10.

inf., stop a person from . . , ἔμʼ ἔπαυσας ἐπὶ Τρώεσσι μάχεσθαι Il. 11.442 ; ῥαψῳδοὺς ἔπαυσε ἀγωνίζεσθαι Hdt. 5.67, cf. 7.54 : sts. with μή inserted, θνητούς γʼ ἔπαυσα μὴ προδέρκεσθαι μόρον A. Pr. 250 ; παύσας ὑμᾶς μὴ λίαν ἐξαπατᾶσθαι Ar. Ach. 634 ; also π. τὸ μὴ προσελθεῖν . . τὴν ὁλκάδα Th. 7.53 ; π. τοῦ . . εἶναι Pl. R. 416c.

data.quote: θνητούς γʼ ἔπαυσα μὴ προδέρκεσθαι μόρον
π. τὸ μὴ προσελθεῖν . . τὴν ὁλκάδα

children.label: b
children.definition: Med. c. inf., Batr. 193, AP 6.21.8, and later Prose, as Plu. Apophth. Lac. 2.216d.
Med., yield, give, of timber, opp. ἵστασθαι, Thphr. HP 5.6.3.

children.label: II
children.definition: παῦε, cease, leave off ( παύου is rare, S. Ichn. 359, Ephipp. 5.20, Luc. Im. 2), παῦε μάχης Hes. Sc. 449 codd., cf. h.Cer. 351 ; παῦε γόοιο Epigr.Gr. 320.5 ( Thyatira) : mostly abs., παῦε stop! have done! be quiet! παῦε, μὴ λέξῃς πέρα S. Ph. 1275, cf. Ar. V. 1208, Ra. 122, 269, Pl. Phdr. 228e ; παῦε, παῦε, μὴ βόα Ar. Av. 1504, cf. V. 1194 ; also παῦε, παῦε τοῦ λόγου Id. Ra. 580 ; παῦε, παῦʼ ὀρχούμενος Id. Pax 326 ; παῦʼ ἐς κόρακας Id. Ach. 864, where the other Verbs are pl. ; παῦ, apoc. for παῦε, παῦ, μηδὲν ὄμνυʼ Men. Sam. 96, cf. Ael.Dion. Fr. 275, etc.: also imper. Med., παῦσαι λέγουσα E. Hipp. 706 ; παῦσαι φαρμακοπωλῶν Ar. Fr. 28 ; π. μελῳδοῦσʼ Com.Adesp. 601 ; π. δυσωνῶν Pl.Com. 224, cf. Theopomp.Com. 62, Philetaer. 6, Philem. 213.1 ; παύσασθε νοῦν ἔχοντες (leg. λέγοντες) Men. 482.1.
Paphlagonian, Il. 2.851, al.(pl.) ; of Cleon (with play on παφλάζω), Ar. Eq. 2, 6, Nu. 581, al. :— Adj. Παφλᾰγ-ονικός, ή, όν, X. An. 5.4.13 : ἡ -κή the country, ib. 6.1.15.

definition: παφλάζω, Aeol. παφλάσδω Alc. Supp. 25.4 (p.28 Lobel) :—

children.definition: boil, bluster, of the sea, κύματα παφλάζοντα Il. 13.798 ; αἰθὴρ παφλάζων καταΐσσεται Emp. 100.7 ; of boiling soup, Ar. Fr. 498 ; λοπὰς π. βαρβάρῳ λαλήματι Eub. 109 :— Med., ἔγχελυς . . παφλάζεται Antiph. 217.4.

children.label: II
children.definition: splutter, bluster, of Cleon (cf. foreg.), Ar. Pax 314, Eq. 919 ; κόμποις π. Timocl. 15.3.
κραδίη πάφλαζεν, of passion, Musae. 91.
seethe, τοῖς λωποδύταις ὁ πόρος π. Cratin. 206.
π. τῇ γλώσσῃ stammer, stutter, Hp. Epid. 2.5.2, Judic. 43. (Redupl., perh. cf. φλέδων.)
boiling : metaph., in pl., blusterings, Ar. Av. 1243.
Paphos, Od. 8.363, h.Ven. 59 :— Adj. Πάφιος[ ᾰ], α, ον, freq. of Aphrodite, νὴ τὴν Π. Ἀφροδίτην Ar. Lys. 556 : abs. ἡ Παφίη AP 5.30 (Antip. Thess.), 93 ( Rufin.), etc.
γῆ PTeb. 214 (ii B. C.).

thick, massive, twice in Od., λάβε δίσκον μείζονα καὶ πάχετον 8.187 ; πάχετος δʼ ἦν ἠΰτε κίων 23.191. (Wrongly expld. by Hsch. and EM 656.53 as sync. from παχύτερον ; for the termination cf. περιμήκετος.)
tight, of a knot or ligature, Hp. Mul. 2.110 : neut. as Adv., Id. Cord. 6.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ep. as neut. Subst., = πάχος, thickness, Nic. Th. 385 (dub.), 387, 465, Opp. H. 4.535 codd. (Oxyt. in codd. Hp. ll. cc.)
fleshy, stout, Tz. H. 9.305.

children.label: II
children.definition: πάχητες· πλούσιοι, παχεῖς, Hsch. ; cf. παχύς II.

hoar-frost, rime (defined as frozen rain, Posidon. ap. D.L. 7.153), Od. 14.476 ; π. ἑῴα A. Pr. 25 ; τὸ ἐπὶ γῆς συμπαγὲν ἐκ δρόσου γενόμενον π. λέγεται Pl. Ti. 59e ; opp. κρύσταλλος, Theognet. 1.3 : pl., πάχναι καὶ χάλαζαι Pl. Smp. 188b ; ἀπέκαυσεν ἡ π. τὰς ἀμπέλους Philippid. 25.4.

data.quote: τὸ ἐπὶ γῆς συμπαγὲν ἐκ δρόσου γενόμενον π. λέγεται

children.definition: γήρως εὐρῶτα καὶ πάχνην the mould and frost of age, descriptive of an old manʼs grey hair, Com.Adesp. 650a, cf. 381 ; π. κουροβόρος clotted blood of the eaten children, A. Ag. 1512 (lyr.).
frosty, Nonn. D. 3.4.
congeal, solidify, Plu. Pyth. 2.396b :— Pass., ib. QConv. 736a.

children.label: b
children.definition: πεπαχνῶσθαι to be covered with rime, Gp. 12.17.1.

strike chill, ἐπάχνωσεν φίλον ἦτορ made his blood curdle, Hes. Op. 360 :— mostly in Pass., ἦτορ παχνοῦται his heart is cold and stiff [with grief], Il. 17.112 ; παχνοῦσθαι πένθεσιν, λύπῃ, A. Ch. 83 (lyr.), E. Hipp. 803 : in later Prose, ἐπαχνώθη J. BJ 1.28.3.
Gp. 1.12.27 : metaph., chill, cold, αὐχμός Hymn.Is. 146.

thickness, τόσσον ἔην μῆκος τόσσον π. Od. 9.324 ; εἰ ἔχοι π. ἔχοι ἂν μόρια Meliss. 9 ; τὸ π. τοῦ τείχους Th. 1.93 ; τῆς πλίνθου Id. 3.20 : pl., τὰ π. τῶν τριχῶν Arist. HA 517b8 ; τὰ π. αὐτῶν ἐκμυελιεῖ LXX Nu. 24.8 ; σκήνεια ὀρθὰ καὶ πάχη ἔχοντα PCair.Zen. 353.11 (iii B. C.) : abs., πάχος in thickness, Hdt. 4.81, IG 1(2).372.11 ; also πάχει μάκει τε Pi. P. 4.245.

data.quote: εἰ ἔχοι π. ἔχοι ἂν μόρια

children.definition: σαρκὸς π. stoutness, E. Cyc. 380 ; διὰ πάχος τοῦ σώματος Antiph. 19 ; opp. λεπτότης, Pl. R. 523e, etc.
consistency, thickness, of liquids or fluids, Arist. Sens. 441a29, GA 739a12 ; τὸ π. τῆς θαλάσσης, attributed to its saltness, Id. Mete. 359a7 ; ὥστε γίνεσθαι τὸ π. ὡς κυκεῶνα Ph. Bel. 89.21.

data.quote: ὥστε γίνεσθαι τὸ π. ὡς κυκεῶνα

children.definition: thick mass, Dsc. 5.18.
thick-blooded, Hp. Vict. 2.46.
swelling of the eyelids, Cyran. 35.
thick-fingered, Polem.Phgn. 86.
thick with trees, ἄλση Him. Or. 23.17.
to be thick-skinned, Gloss.
thickness of skin, Hp. Epid. 5.9.
thick-skinned, Arist. GA 783a2 : Comp., ib. 782b5.
dull, stupid, Men. Epit. 574, Luc. Tim. 23.
with thick hair: Comp. -τριχώτερος Arist. GA 782b5.
thick-stalked, Thphr. CP 3.21.2.
Gloss.
with a thick stalk or stem, Thphr. HP 6.2.6 ( Comp.).
with fat or thick legs, Ar. Pl. 560, D.L. 7.1.
Dim. of παχύς, thickish : only Adv. - λῶς coarsely, roughly, opp. ἀκριβῶς, Arist. EN 1094b20.
thickness of parts, S.E. M. 9.86 ; opp. λεπτομέρεια, Theo Sm. p.97 H.

consisting of thick or coarse parts, Ti.Locr. 100e ( Comp.), Arist. Pr. 873a6 ; ἀήρ Corn. ND 5 ( Sup.); τὸ παχυμερές the dense part, Epicur. Ep. 2p.51U. ; τὸ -έστερον, opp. τὸ λεπτομερέστερον, Arist. Cael. 304a31 ; τὸ -έστατον Placit. 1.3.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adv., loosely, broadly, roughly, εἴρηται παχυμερῶς Str. 1.4.7, cf. 8 ( Comp.), Ach.Tat. Intr.Arat. 18 ; cursorily, ἐξετάζειν Just. Nov. 53.4.1.
have swollen sinews, Str. 14.5.12.
thick-witted, Hsch., Phot. (- νοοὶ and -νοες).
thickening, Arist. Mete. 383a11, Thphr. CP 6.11.7 ; hardening of eggs by boiling, Gal. 6.707.
having the power of thickening, c. gen., Dsc. 5.71 ; fattening, Ath.Med. ap. Orib. inc. 23.27 ; τροφαί Sor. 1.21.

definition: παχύνω, pf. Pass. πεπάχυσμαι Arist. Mu. 394a28, Philostr. Gym. 52, but πεπάχυμμαι Gal. 6.678, Herm. ap. Stob. 1.49.68 :—

children.definition: fatten, τὰ σώματα Pl. Grg. 518c ; βοῦν Id. R. 343b ; ἴππον X. Oec. 12.20 :— Pass., grow fat, Hp. Aph. 5.44, Ar. Ach. 791 ; δαιτὶ παχυνόμενος AP 7.207 ( Mel.) ; παχυνθῇ ἡ ἀκρίς LXX Ec. 12.5.

children.label: b
children.definition: thicken, strengthen, δεσμόν Porph. Abst. 1.38.
cause to wax fat, increase, κότον π. A. Supp. 618 :— Pass., ὄλβος ἄγαν παχυνθείς Id. Th. 771 (lyr.).

children.label: b
children.definition: make gross or dull, τὰς ψυχὰς ὑπὸ πλης μονῆς π. Plu. Es. carn. 1 2.995d ; βρώσεις τὸν νοῦν π. Philostr. VA 1.8 :— Pass., LXX Is. 6.10 ; πεπαχυσμένος Philostr. VS 1.21.1 ; to be coarsened, [ ψυχὴ] παρὰ τὴν ἰδίαν φύσιν πεπαχυμμένη Herm. l.c. ; περιβλήματα . . παχυνόμενα ὑπὸ τῆς γηίνης φύσεως Procl. in R. 1.119 K.

data.quote: ψυχὴ] παρὰ τὴν ἰδίαν φύσιν πεπαχυμμένη
περιβλήματα . . παχυνόμενα ὑπὸ τῆς γηίνης φύσεως

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., become thick, π. πρὸς τὸν ἥλιον, of the skull, Hdt. 3.12 ; of humours, Hp. VM 19 ; of excrements, Id. Prog. 11, cf. Arist. GA 735a36, al.; distd. from πήγνυσθαι, Id. Mete. 383a11, b18 ; of fruit juices, become concentrated, Thphr. CP 6.16.2 ; of oil, Philostr. Gym. 52.
to be dulled, of the sunʼs light, D.P. 35.
thick-footed, v.l. in Arist. HA 557a23, cf. Adam. 2.48.

definition: παχύριν, ῑνος, ὁ, ἡ, better παχύρριν,

children.definition: thick-nosed, PPetr. 3p.13 ( -ρρ-, iii B. C.), Adam. 2.48.
with thick shoots, Dsc. [1.14] ( Comp.).
with thick roots, Thphr. HP 3.11.4, Dsc. 1.14.
thick-snouted, Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.141.

definition: παχύς, εῖα ( Ion. -έα Hp. Superf. 21), ύ,

children.definition: thick, stout, χειρὶ παχείῃ Il. 5.309, etc. ; παχέος παρὰ μηροῦ 16.473 ; παχὺν αὐχένα Od. 9.372 ; π. πούς Hes. Op. 497 ; of trees, ib. 509 ; ῥίζα Thphr. HP 6.3.1 ; later of persons, περὶ σφυρὸν παχεῖα, μισήτη γυνή thick-ankled, Archil. 184 ; fat, οἱ παχύτατοι τῶν παίδων Hp. Aph. 3.25 ; π. γυνή Id. Superf. l.c.; χοῖρος π., ὗς π., Ar. Ach. 766, Men. 21 : metaph., of soil, rich, fertile, X. Oec. 17.8 ( Comp.) ; π. τράπεζα a well-spread table, Philostr. VA 3.26. Adv., παχέως διαιτᾶσθαι ibid.

thick, massive, π. λᾶας Il. 12.446 ; σκῆπτρον 18.416 ; αὐλὸς αἵματος Od. 22.18 ; θρυαλλίδες Ar. Nu. 59 ; πέδαι Id. V. 435 ; π. δραχμή a thick drachma, i. e. the Aeginetan, which weighed more than the Attic, Poll. 9.76, or ( Hsch.), = δίδραχμον ; thick, coarse, opp. λεπτός, ἱμάτιον Pl. Cra. 389b, cf. Poll. 7.57, 61, etc.; χλαῖναν . . παχεῖαν ἐπιβαλῶ Λακωνικήν Theopomp.Com. 10 ; of hair, Arist. HA 502a26 ; π. τὴν σάρκα, of the pig, Jul. Or. 5.177c. Adv. coarsely, roughly, of stating or arguing, παχέως ὁρίζεσθαι, prob. for ταχέως, Arist. Pol. 1275b25 ; παχύτερον or -έρως, Pl. Plt. 294e, 295a.

thick, curdled, clotted, αἷμα Il. 23.697 ; ἀπορρέει . . παχὺ καὶ μέλαν Hdt. 4.23 ; of marsh water, Hp. Aër. 7; of urine, Id. Prog. 12 ; τὸ παχύτερον τῶν γαλάκτων Arist. HA 521b28 ; τὸ παχὺ τῆς δυνάμεως [τῶν οἴνων] Ath. 1.33b.

children.label: b
children.definition: τὰ παχέα καλούμενα νοσήματα, of certain diseases supposed to be due to thickened phlegm, Hp. Int. 47, al.
fat, great, π. πρᾶγμα, χάρις, Ar. Lys. 23, Ec. 1048.
thick, opp. λεπτός, Arist. Aud. 803b29, cf. 804a10 ( Comp.). Adv., κορώνη παχέα κρώζουσα Arat. 953.
coarse, heavy, διάλεκτος παχυτέρα D.H. Pomp. 2 ; παχύτερος τὴν λέξιν Id. Is. 19 ; παχύτερον ποιεῖν τὸν λόγον Hermog. Id. 1.6.

children.label: b
children.definition: ample, of periphrasis, Longin. 29.1 ( Sup.).
dull, Thphr. HP 5.9.3.

children.label: II
children.definition: οἱ παχέες men of substance, the wealthy, Hdt. 5.30, 77, 6.91 ; τοὺς π. καὶ πλουσίους Ar. Pax 639 ; ὃς ἂν ᾖ π. Id. Eq. 1139 ; ἀνὴρ π. Id. V. 287 ; cf. πάχης.

children.label: III
children.definition: thick-witted, gross, stupid, ἀμαθὴς καὶ π. Id. Nu. 842 ; τὸ τῶν παχυτέρων πλῆθος Phld. Rh. 1.202 S.; π. καὶ ἠλίθιοι, π. καὶ ἀπαίδευτοι, Luc. Alex. 9, 17 ; ἐς τὰς τέχνας π. καὶ οὐ λεπτοὶ οὐδὲ ὀξέες Hp. Aër. 24 ; π. τὴν μνήμην Philostr. VS 2.1.10 ; π. λόγος Gal. 8.606. Adv., παχύτερον ἔχειν τῆς ἀκοῆς Hld. 5.18.

data.quote: ἐς τὰς τέχνας π. καὶ οὐ λεπτοὶ οὐδὲ ὀξέες

children.label: IV
children.definition: πηλοῦ παχύτερος, of a dullard, Eun. Hist. p.265 D.

children.label: V
children.definition: Adv. -έως, v. supr.

children.label: VI
children.definition: Comp. πάσσων, ον, Od. 6.230, 8.20, 24.369 ; πᾰχίων, ον, Arat. 785 : Sup. πάχιστος Il. 16.314, Call. Aet. Oxy. 2079.23 [Fr. 1.23 Pf.] : regul. forms πᾰχύτερος, πᾰχύτατος (v. supr.). (I.-E. bhṇĝhú-, cf. Skt. bahús, Lett. biezs ‘thick’.)
with stout fibres, Dsc. 1.85.
thick-legged, Lyr.Adesp. 21, Gal. 6.322, Adam. 2.31.
thickening, Aët. 1.59.

children.label: II
children.definition: τὰς μερικὰς ψυχὰς ἀπὸ τῶν π. χωρίζων τῆς ὕλης Procl. in Cra. p.101 P.

data.quote: τὰς μερικὰς ψυχὰς ἀπὸ τῶν π. χωρίζων τῆς ὕλης

children.definition: a growing fat, Hp. Epid. 6.8.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: thickening, νεύρων Damocr. ap. Gal. 13.988.
having thick semen, Gal. 1.339.
thick at the brim, κώθων Henioch. 1 ; with a large mouth, of the oyster, Arist. Fr. 304.

children.label: II
children.definition: speaking with a broad accent, π. ἢ τραχύστομοι, of the Κᾶρες βαρβαρόφωνοι, Str. 14.2.28 :—hence πᾰχυ-στομέω, πᾰχυ-στομία, ibid.
thickness, of stalks, skin, ropes, Hdt. 4.74, 183, 7.36 ; of hair, Arist. GA 782a24 ; of animals, fatness, Id. HA 611a25 : pl., v.l. in Pl. Plt. 284e.
thickness or sediment of liquor, Hdt. 4.23 ; density, Hp. Aph. 6.41 ; thick consistency, αἵματος, γάλακτος, Arist. PA 668b2, 676a11 ; π. ἀέρος Ascl. Tact. 12.10.

children.label: II
children.definition: thickness of wit, dullness, D.H. Dem. 26, S.E. M. 1.70.
bull-necked, Adam. 2.21.
with thick rind or bark, Thphr. HP 1.5.2, Dsc. 1.13, Gal. 6.270, Gp. 10.75.2.
Tz. H. 5.716, Hsch. s.v. Βοῦθος περιφοιτᾷ.
of coarse sound, στοιχεῖον Aristid. Quint. 1.21 ( Comp.).
thick-lipped, of shell-fish, Arist. HA 528a29 :—also πᾰχύ-χειλος, ον, Ruf. Fr. 70 ; τὰ π. τῶν ἑλκῶν Gal. 13.491.
with thick juices, Gal. 6.261, Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.52, etc.
pavo), = ταὧς, Edict.Diocl. 4.39,40.

definition: παώταρ ( παθιώταρ cod.), α, ὁ, Lacon. for παός, πηός, Hsch., who also has π[ρ]αῶται· συγγενεῖς, οἰκεῖοι, Λάκωνες.
πε, reduced form (before initial τ) of πετ (ά) ,

children.definition: IG 5(2).6.98 ( Tegea, iv B. C.), 262.16 (Mantinea, V B.C.).
Aeol. for μετά, Sapph. 38, Alc. 48 A, Pi. Fr. 26, Theoc. 29.38 : also Dor., Leg.Gort. 3.27 ; πεδʼ ἰαρόν Schwyzer 89.14 ( Argos, iii B. C.). (Cogn. with πούς.)

definition: Πεδαγείτνυος, ὁ, name of a month at Rhodes, etc., = Att. Μεταγειτνιών, GDI 4245.298 ( Rhodes) :—also Πεδᾰγείτνιος, IG 12(1).1104.1 (ibid.) ; Πετᾰγείτνυος, SIG 1106.60 ( Cos) ; Πετᾰγείτνιος, ib. 1009.19 ( Chalcedon).
πεδάγρετος, ον, Aeol. for * μετάγρετος ( ἀγρέω), in neut. sg., glossed μεταμέλητον, μεταληπτόν, ποικίλον, μεταδίωκτον, Hsch.

children.definition: Schwyzer 89.16 ( Argos, iii B. C.).

definition: πεδαίρω, Aeol. or Dor. for μεταίρω (q.v.).
πεδαίχμιος, ον, Aeol. or Dor. for μετ-, A. Ch. 589 (lyr.).
πέδαλα ποικίλα, Hsch. πεδαλευόμενος· μεταμελόμενος, μεταδιωκόμενος, ld., cf. Alc. 50.4 Pap. Demetr.Lacon.
πεδαμείβω, Aeol. for μεταμείβω, Pi. O. 12.12.

children.definition: low-growing, short, ἀλκαίη, οὐρή, Nic. Th. 226, 289.

children.label: II
children.definition: light, ὕπνος Ion Trag. 4 ( ἠπεδ- Hsch.).

definition: πεδάϝοικος, ον, Dor. for μέτοικος, IG 4.552,615 ( Argos).

children.definition: Aeol. and Dor. for μετήορος, μετέωρος, Alc. 100; cf. μετήορος I fin. and πεδήορος.

definition: πεδάρσιος, ον, Aeol. or Dor. for μετάρσιος, A. Pr. 271, 710, 916, Ch. 846, Ar. Av. 1197 (paratrag.).

children.definition: Pythag. word for μεθαρμόζω, = νουθετέω, ἐκάλουν δὲ τὸ νουθετεῖν πεδαρτᾶν (Schäfer for παιδ.) Iamb. VP 31.197 ; ἐκάλει [Πυθαγόρας] τὸ νουθετεῖν πεδαρτᾶν (to be restored for πελαργᾶν) D.L. 8.20, cf. Suid. ; τὰς . . νουθετήσεις, ἃς δὴ πεδαρτάσεις ἐκάλουν Iamb. VP 22.101, 33.231.

definition: πέδασος, dub. sens. in UPZ 149 i 19 (iii/ii B. C.).
πεδαυγάζω, Aeol. for μεταυγάζω, Pi. N. 10.61.

children.definition: removal, IG 42(1).102.276 ( Epid., iv B. C.).

definition: πεδάω, Ep. 3 sg. πεδάᾳ Od. 4.380 : Ep. and Ion. impf. πεδάασκον 23.353 : pf. part. Pass. πεπεδημένος Paus. 8.49.6 : ( πέδη) :—

children.definition: bind with fetters : hence, simply, bind, make fast, ἐπέδησε θύρας (unless this be from ἐπιδέω) Od. 21.391 ; π. ἄνδρα δαιδάλῳ πέπλῳ A. Eu. 635 ; τὸν μούναρχον πεδήσας Hdt. 6.23.

shackle, trammel, πέδησε δὲ φαίδιμα γυῖα Il. 13.435 ; δόλῳ ἅρμα πεδῆσαι 23.585, cf. Pi. P. 6.32, N. 5.26 ; ἕρκος Ἀχαιῶν θρασεῖ φόνῳ πεδάσαις Id. Pae. 6.86 ; νῆα θοὴν ἐπέδησʼ ἐνὶ πόντῳ Od. 13.168 ; of sleep, ὅς μʼ ἐπέδησε φίλα βλέφαρʼ ἀμφικαλύψας 23.17 ; ὕπνος λύει πεδήσας S. Aj. 676 ; esp. of a deity or fate overruling a mortalʼs will, μοῖρʼ ἐπέδησε c. acc. pers., Il. 4.517 ; ὅς τίς μʼ ἀθανάτων πεδάᾳ Od. 4.380 ; πέδησε δὲ καὶ τὸν Ἀθήνη 18.155 ; ἐμὲ θεοὶ πεδάασκον ἐμῆς ἀπὸ πατρίδος αἴης 23.353 : c. inf., Ἕκτορα δʼ αὐτοῦ μεῖναι . . μοῖρʼ ἐπέδησε constrained him to remain on the spot, Il. 22.5 ; μιν μοῖρα θεῶν ἐπέδησε δαμῆναι constrained him to be slain, Od. 3.269 ; τό γε Μοῖρʼ ἐπέδησε οὖλον ἀκίνητόν τʼ ἔμεναι Parm. 8.37, cf. 10.6 : rare in Prose, καθʼ ὕπνον τὴν τῆς φρονήσεως πεδηθεὶς δύναμιν Pl. Ti. 71e, cf. 43d, Plot. 3.5.7 ; εἰ πεδᾶται ὁ ταὐτοῦ κύκλος Dam. Pr. 400 ; τῷ ἀξιώματι πεδηθείς D.C. 60.29.

data.quote: ὅς μʼ ἐπέδησε φίλα βλέφαρʼ ἀμφικαλύψας
ἐμὲ θεοὶ πεδάασκον ἐμῆς ἀπὸ πατρίδος αἴης
τό γε Μοῖρʼ ἐπέδησε οὖλον ἀκίνητόν τʼ ἔμεναι
καθʼ ὕπνον τὴν τῆς φρονήσεως πεδηθεὶς δύναμιν

definition: πεδαωριστής, οῦ, ὁ, Aeol. or Dor. for ἵππος φρυαγματίας, μετεωριστής, Hsch. (fort. πεδαορ-). πεδεινός,

children.definition: πεδέπω, Aeol. = μεθέπω (q.v.). πεδέρχομαι, v. μετέρχομαι III, IV. 5 : aor. imper. πέδελθε, = ἱκέτευσον, Id. ; subj. πεδέλθῃ, = ἱκετεύῃ, Id. (prob.). πέδευρα· ὕστερα ( Lacon.), Id., and πέδευρον· ὕστερον, πάλιν, ὀπίσω ( Lacon.), Id.
Aeol. for μετέχω, Alc., Sapph. (v. μετέχω, Pi. Pae. 4.37 : aor. inf. πεδασχεῖν Id. Fr. 27 ; also Dor., Abh.Berl.Akad. 1925(5).21 ( Cyrene).

fetter : in pl., shackles, ἀμφὶ δὲ ποσσὶ πέδας ἔβαλε χρυσείας, of horses, Il. 13.36 ; of men, τοῖς ἀδίκοις ἀμφιτίθησι πέδας Sol. 4.34, cf. Thgn. 539, A. Pr. 6, Men. Her. 3, Herod. 3.95 ; πεδέων ζεῦγος pair of fetters, Hdt. 7.35 ; ἐν πέδαις (v.l. ἐς πέδας) δῆσαί τινα put one in fetters, Id. 5.77 ; αἱ πέδαι, ἐν τῇσι ἐδεδέατο ibid. ; ἐν πέδαις δῆσαι, φυλάττειν, etc., Pl. Lg. 882b, Plu. Apophth.reg. 2.181b, etc. : metaph., πέδαις ἀχαλκεύτοισι, of the robe in which Agamemnon was entangled, A. Ch. 493 ; πέδας χειροῖν καὶ ποδοῖν ib. 982 : in sg., of the poisoned robe of Nessus, S. Tr. 1057 ; π. Ἑλληνικαί, of the fortresses of Chalcis, Corinth, and Demetrias, Plb. 18.11.5, etc.
anklet, bangle, Ar. Fr. 320.11, Philem. 81, Luc. Lex. 9.

children.label: II
children.definition: mode of breaking in a horse by riding him in a figure-of-eight course (cf. ἱπποπέδη), X. Eq. 3.5, 7.13 ; π. ἑτερομήκης, κυκλοτερής, ib. 14.
Nic. Th. 729.
one who fetters : metaph., hinderer, AP 9.756 ( Aemil.).
one fettered, prisoner, Ar. Fr. 65, Herod. 3.69, LXX Wi. 17.2, Plu. Superst. 2.165e, Luc. Sat. 10, etc. : in pl., title of play by Call.Com. ( Fr. 2 D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.303e.
of or on the plain, τὰ π. Lys. Fr. 238 S.

children.label: II
children.definition: π., οἱ, in Attica, party of the plain, Arist. Pol. 1305a24, Ath. 13.4 ; cf. πεδιάσιος, πεδιεῖς.
send for, aor. inf. πεδιᾶλαι, Hsch.

definition: πεδιανόμος, ὁ, title of magistrate at Sparta, IG 5(1).123.
πεδιάς, άδος, used as fem. of πεδιεινός,

children.definition: flat, level, of Scythia, Hdt. 4.23, 47, Hp. Aër. 18; of Egypt, Hdt. 2.8 ; of Thessaly, Pl. Lg. 625d ; ἡ π. (sc. γῆ) Hdt. 9.122, Onos. 6.8 ; π. ὁδός, ἁμαξιτός, Pi. P. 5.91, E. Rh. 283 ; ἡ π. χώρα Plb. 2.16.7.

children.label: II
children.definition: on or of the plain, ὕλη S. Ant. 420 ; λόγχη π. the spearmen of the plain, Id. Tr. 1058 ; π. μάχη battle in the plain, Plu. Sull. 19, prob. in IG 14.1290.59.
campester, Gloss.
of the plain, σμύρνα Dsc. 1.64 (v.l. -άσιμος) ; οἱ π. dwellers in the plain, Str. 15.1.58 ; = πεδιεῖς, Phot., Suid. s.v. πάραλοι.

flat, level, χῶρος Hdt. 7.198 (v.l. πεδινός) ; πεδιναὶ ὑποχωρήσεις Plb. 1.34.8 ; τὰ πεδινά Arist. Pr. 880b28, Aen.Tact. 1.2, Onos. 18, Plu. Nic. 26 : Comp. πεδιεινότερος Pl. Lg. 704d ; πεδινώτερος X. An. 5.5.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: of the plain, found on the plain, opp. ὄρειος, λαγώς Id. Cyn. 5.17. ( πεδινός, v.l. πεδεινός) ; [δένδρα] πεδεινά Thphr. HP 1.8.1, cf. 3.11.2 ; πεδινὸν ἄνθος, = ἀργεμώνη, Ps.- Dsc. 2.177. ( πεδιεινός may have become πεδῑνός (written also πεδεινός) about 150 B.C. ; πεδῐνός is dub., since πεδινώτερος may be f. l. in X. An. l.c.)
party of the plain (cf. πεδιακός II), Plu. Sol. 13, D.L. 1.58.
fetter, Gloss.
abounding in plains, Θρῄκης ἂμ πεδιήρεις (vulg. ἀμπεδιήρεις) . . κελεύθους A. Pers. 566 (lyr.).

definition: πέδιλον, Aeol. πέδιλλον Choerob. in An.Ox. 2.239 : τό : ( πέδη) :— mostly in pl.,

children.definition: sandals, ἀμφὶ πόδεσσιν . . ἀράρισκε π., τάμνων δέρμα βόειον Od. 14.23 ; ὑπὸ ποσσὶν ἐδήσατο καλὰ π. ἀμβρόσια χρύσεια, τά μιν φέρον ἠμὲν ἐφʼ ὑγρὴν ἠδʼ ἐπʼ ἀπείρονα γαῖαν, of Hermes, Il. 24.340 ; of Athena, Od. 1.96 ; πτερόεντα π. Hes. Sc. 220 ; ποτανά E. El. 460 (lyr.).

data.quote: ἀμφὶ πόδεσσιν . . ἀράρισκε π., τάμνων δέρμα βόειον

children.label: II
children.definition: any covering for the feet, shoes or boots, π. ἐς γόνυ ἀνατείνοντα Hdt. 7.67 ; περὶ τοὺς πόδας τε καὶ τὰς κνήμας π. νεβρῶν ib. 75, cf. Pi. P. 4.95, Plu. Thes. 3 ; ἱμάτιον καθαρὸν καὶ καινὰ π. Ar. Av. 973.

children.label: III
children.definition: Δωρίῳ φωνὰν ἐναρμόξαι π., i.e. to write in Doric rhythm (cf. πούς), Pi. O. 3.5 ; also ἐν τούτῳ π. πόδʼ ἔχειν to have oneʼs foot in this shoe, i.e. to be in this condition or fortune, ib. 6.8.

definition: πέδιον, τό, Dim. of πέδη, EM 658.23.

children.definition: plain, in Hom. mostly sg., Il. 5.222, al. : in pl., 12.283, Hes. Op. 388, etc. ; ἐν πεδίῳ on a fertile plain, opp. ἐν πέτραις, Men. 719.

children.label: b
children.definition: δελφινοφόρον πεδίον πόντου A. Fr. 150 ; πόντου π. Αἰγαῖον Ion Trag. 60 ; π. πλόϊμα Tim. Pers. 89.

πεδίον Αἰσώπου A. Ag. 297 ; τὸ Τροίας π. S. Ph. 1435 (but τὰ Τ. π. 1376) ; τὸ Θήβης π. Id. OC 1312 ; Καϋστρίων π. Ar. Ach. 68 ; τὸ Κιρραῖον π. Aeschin. 3.107 ; τὰ Θετταλικὰ π. Pl. Plt. 264c ; τὸ Ἄρειον π., = Lat. Campus Martius, D.H. 7.59.

children.label: b
children.definition: the plain of Attica, IG 1(2).842 C7, Hdt. 1.59, Th. 2.55, Is. 5.22.
ἱππέας εἰς π. προκαλεῖσθαι, prov. of challenging persons to do that in which they excel, Pl. Tht. 183d, cf. Men. 268.

children.label: II
children.definition: part of the foot next the toes, metatarsus, Gal. UP 3.5, al., Poll. 2.197.

children.label: III
children.definition: pudenda muliebria, Ar. Lys. 88.
to the plain, Il. 11.492, Od. 15.183, h.Merc. 88, Ar. Av. 507.
dwelling in the plain, π. θεοί rural deities, A. Th. 272.

definition: πέδιjος, α, ον, Cypr. pe-ti-ja-i, situated in the plain, ICS 217 B18. [corr. from Supp.-HD]

children.definition: having a plain, gloss on στερνοῦχος, Sch. S. OC 691.
guard of an estate, PFay. 113.4 (100 A.D.), PLond. 2.189.20 (ii A. D.), etc.
Dim. of πέδη, small fetter, IG 7.2420.27 ( Thebes, iii B.C.).
goddess of the Plain, epith. of Hera, IG 14.595,596 ( Sicily).
like a plain, level, Sch. S. OC 691.
IG 12(3).1259.17 ( Cimolus, iv B.C.).
earth-walking, πτανά τε καὶ π. A. Ch. 591 (lyr.).
Nic. Th. 662.
from the ground, Hes. Th. 680, E. Tr. 98 (anap.).

children.label: II
children.definition: from the bottom, Pi. O. 7.62 : metaph., οἵ τοι π. φίλοι εἰσίν which are dear to thee from the bottom of thy heart, Od. 13.295.
from the beginning, Pi. I. 5(4).38.
on the ground, on earth, A. Pr. 274 ; cf. πέδον 4.
Aeol. and Dor. for μέτοικος, Pi. Fr. 25 ; π. χελιδών A. Fr. 53.
go in search of, pursue, παιηόνων ἄνθεα B. 15.9.
lying on the ground, σίκυος AP 6.102 ( Phil.).

ground, earth, first in h.Cer. 455 ( πέδονδε is used in Hom.) : freq. in later Poetry, Pi. O. 10.46, P. 1.28, etc. ; χθονὸς π. A. Pr. 1 ; γῆς π. Ar. Nu. 573 (lyr.) ; π. κελεύθου στρωννύναι A. Ag. 909.

Ζηνὸς εὐθαλὲς π., of Nemea, B. 8.5 ; Κρισαῖον π. S. El. 730 ; Λοξίου π. A. Ch. 1036 ; Παλλάδος κλεινὸν π., i.e. the Acropolis, Ar. Pl. 772 ; ἁγνὸν ἐς Θήβης π. Eub. 10, cf. 66 ; πέδον c. gen. loci periphr. for the place itself, Εὐρώπης π. A. Pr. 734 ; Λήμνου. S. Ph. 1464 (anap.), etc.
νεύειν ἐς π. Id. Ant. 441 ; πρὸς πέδῳ βαλεῖν, κεῖσθαι, A. Fr. 183, S. OT 180 (lyr.).

πέδῳ on the ground, to earth, h.Cer. 455 ; πεσόντος αἵματος π. A. Ch. 48 (lyr.), cf. Eu. 263 (lyr.), 479, S. El. 747 ; ῥίπτειν πέδῳ E. IA 39 (anap.), cf. Or. 1433, 1440 (both lyr.) ; πέδῳ σκήψασα A. Pr. 749 ; πέδοι shd. perh. be read for πέδῳ in Trag., as also for πέδον in the phrases πέδον πατεῖν, πέδον πατεῖσθαι, A. Ag. 1357, Ch. 643 (lyr.).
to the ground, earthwards, Il. 13.796, h.Cer. 253, S. Tr. 786.
to the bottom, π. κυλίνδετο λᾶας ἀναιδής Od. 11.598.
rising from the ground, κτύπος S. Ichn. 212.
ἡμέρα ἐν ᾗ οὐ γίνεται ἑορτή, Hsch.
E. Ba. 136, 600 (both lyr.).
earth-shaker, coined as etym. of Ποσειδῶν, Corn. ND 4.
digging the earth, Nonn. D. 12.331.
earth-treading, opp. πτεροῦς, A. Supp. 1000 ; ὄχος, πούς, E. Med. 1123, Hel. 1516 ; ηὕδομεν πεδοστιβεῖς Id. Rh. 763 (s.v.l.).
on foot, opp. ἱππηλάτης, λεώς A. Pers. 127 (lyr.).
wearing the ground, Nonn. D. 10.361.

definition: πεδότριψ, ῐβος, ὁ and ἡ, ( πέδη, τρίβω)

children.definition: wearing out fetters, Com. epith. of good-for-nothing slaves, Luc. Sat. 8.
Hsch., Phot.
one in fetters, of a slave, Ar. Fr. 837.
digging the soil, AP 10.101 ( Bianor).

Dor. and Arc. for πούς, Gal. 19.129, cf. Ruf. ap. Orib. 25.1.56 ; τῶν ἄπο πέζαν ἐκτὸς ἔχων Androm. ap. Gal. 14.37 ; but distd. from it as the instep by Poll. 2.192 ; πρὸς πέζῃ ποδός Paus. 5.11.2, cf. AP 12.176 ( Strat.) ; οἱ πόδες οἰδίσκονται καὶ αἱ πέζαι μάλιστα Hp. Mul. 2.169.

data.quote: οἱ πόδες οἰδίσκονται καὶ αἱ πέζαι μάλιστα

children.definition: περίσφυροσπ., = πέδη I.2, AP 6.211 ( Leon.).

children.label: II
children.definition: bottom, end of a body, ἐπὶ ῥυμῷ πέζῃ ἔπι πρώτῃ on the pole at the far end, Il. 24.272.

edge, border of a garment, A.R. 4.46, AP 6.287 ( Antip.), J. AJ 3.7.4, Hld. 3.3 ; of the sea, strand, bank, Ἐλευσῖνος παρὰ πέζαν Hermesian. 7.17 ; of a country, coastline, π. ἠπείροιο A.R. 4.1258, cf. D.P. 61 ; εἰς ὁδοῦ π. στενήν Luc. Trag. 238 ; of a mountain, D.P. 535, App. Pun. 103.

children.label: III
children.definition: round fishing-net, Opp. H. 3.83.
foot-javelin-man, Plb. 3.65.10, 3.72.2.
command infantry, Them. Or. 11.152c.
leader of infantry, X. Cyr. 5.3.41.
trafficking by land, Str. 16.3.3.
foot-guards in the Macedon. army (cf. ἑταῖρος), D. 2.17, Anaximen. Lampsac. 4J., Plu. Flam. 17, Apophth.reg. 2.197c.
able to walk, going on foot, π. ζῷα, opp. πτηνά, νευστικά, Arist. GA 715a27.

go or travel on foot, walk, ἐπὶ γαίας πόδα πεζεύων (where πόδα is pleon.) E. Alc. 869 (anap.) ; οὔτε ἄπουν οὔτε πεζεῦον Arist. PA 669b7 ; π. περὶ τὴν τροφήν, of certain birds, Id. HA 593a25, cf. GA 751b13.

go or travel by land, opp. going by sea, X. An. 5.5.[4], Plb. 16.29.11 ; π. μετὰ τῶν ἵππων Id. 10.48.6 ; οἱ πεζεύοντες land-forces, Arist. Pol. 1327b10 ; π. διὰ τῆς θαλάσσης, of Xerxes passing by his bridge over the Hellespont, Isoc. 4.89 ; π. τὴν θάλασσαν pass it like dry land, Philostr. Im. 1.8 ; simply, march, pass through, ἀνοδίας Ph. 2.257 :— Pass., ὁ Ἄθως πλείσθω καὶ ὁ Ἑλλήσποντος πεζευέσθω Luc. Rh.Pr. 18 ; ἡ ἐκ Βρεντεσίου πεζευομένη ὁδός by land, Str. 6.3.5 ; πεζεύεται impers., ταῖς ἁρμαμάξαις Id. 4.1.14.

data.quote: ὁ Ἄθως πλείσθω καὶ ὁ Ἑλλήσποντος πεζευέσθω

a land force, opp. a fleet, ἥ τε π. καὶ ἡ ναυτικὴ δύναμις Id. Mem. 3.6.9, cf. Th. 6.33, Din. 3.10, Aeschin. 3.85, Plb. 2.2.4, IPE 12.352.39 ( Chersonesus), etc.; πεζός is v.l. and shd. prob. be read in all passages of early writers.

V. 685 ; τισι Th. 1.112 ; π. καὶ ναυμαχοῦντες Isoc. 7.75 ; π. ἀπὸ τῶν νεῶν fight like soldiers from shipboard, Th. 7.62 ; ἐπὶ τῶν νεῶν D.S. 13.16 ; of infantry, opp. cavalry, Lyd. Mag. 1.11.
battle by land, opp. ναυμαχία, Hdt. 8.15, Th. 1.23, etc.
fighting on foot, opp. ἱππομαχία, Ph. 1.191 (pl.), cf. Arr. An. 1.15.4.
fighting on foot, Luc. Macr. 17.

of or for the management of quadrupeds (opp. birds) ; ἡ π. ἐπιστήμη the business of managing them, Pl. Plt. 265c, cf. 264e ; τὸ π. ib. 267b.

go on foot, X. Eq.Mag. 4.1.

children.label: a

Th. 6.33, cf. 7.16 (and v. πεζικός) ; ἡ π. στρατιὰ καὶ τὸ ναυτικόν Lys. 2.34, cf. A. Pers. 558 (lyr.), 719, 728 (both troch.) ; οἱ μὲν ἐφʼ ἵππων, οἱ δʼ ἐπὶ ναῶν, πεζοί τε βάδην ib. 19 ; τὰ π. κράτιστοι strongest by land, Th. 4.12 ; καὶ ναυσὶ καὶ πεζοῖσι Ar. Ach. 622 ; π. μάχαισιν Id. Eq. 567 ; ἡ π. μάχη battle by land, Pl. Lg. 707c ; ἐν τοῖς ναυτικοῖς κινδύνοις, ὥσπερ ἐν τοῖς π. Isoc. 4.91.

children.label: II

Mus. p.87 K. ; λόγος POxy. 724.10 (ii A. D.) ; ἡ π. διάλεκτος D.H. Comp. 3 ; ἡ π. λέξις ib. 1 ; opp. ἡ ἔμμετρος, ib. 4 ; ἡ π. alone, Str. 1.2.6 ; τινὰ καὶ πεζὰ καὶ ἐν ἔπεσι ποιήματα D.C. 69.3 ; π. τις ποιητική, of bombastic prose, Luc. Hist.Conscr. 8 ; κομιδῇ πεζὸν καὶ χαμαιπετές ib. 16, cf. Plu. Comp. Arist. Men. 2.853c ; τὰ ἄγαν π. καὶ κακόμετρα [ὀνόματα] ib. QConv. 747f ; π. ὀνόματα, opp. ποιητικά, Demetr. Eloc. 167.

data.quote: αὐτὰρ ἐγὼ Μουσέων πεζὸς ἔπειμι νομόν
τινὰ καὶ πεζὰ καὶ ἐν ἔπεσι ποιήματα

common, ordinary, ἑταῖραι Theopomp.Hist. 205 ; μόσχοι Eup. 169 ; π. αὐλητρίς Pl.Com. 155.

without musical accompaniment (cf. II.2), παῦσαι μελῳδοῦσʼ ἀλλὰ π. μοι φράσον Com.Adesp. 601, cf. Pl. Sph. 237a.

being furnished with feet, Simp. in Cat. 100.16.
like prose, Procl. in Alc. p.292 C. ( Comp.).
bordered, ζώματα A. Fr. 246.

compulsion under the disguise of persuasion, force majeure, duress, Plb. 21.42.7 ; π. προσάγειν τισὶ τοῦ συγχωρεῖν Id. Fr. 194, cf. Cic. Att. 9.13.4 ; π. Θετταλική ‘Hobsonʼs choice’, Zos. 1.21, cf. Jul. Or. 1.32a ; euphemism for torture or bastinado, PAmh. 2.31. 11 (ii B. C.), PTeb. 5.58 (ii B. C.).

obey one in authority, abs., πειθαρχεῖ . . , ἄπληκτος ὥσπερ ἵππος Eup. 232, cf. Arist. Pol. 1262b3 : mostly c. dat., π. πατρί S. Tr. 1178 ; τοῖς νόμοισι Ar. Ec. 762 ; τοῖς ἐφεστῶσι X. Mem. 3.5.19, cf. Pl. R. 538d; ὡς ἂν . . τοῖς πηδαλίοις ἡ ναῦς π. Cratin. 139 ; τοῖς προσταχθεῖσιν Isoc. 3.13 ; τῷ λόγῳ Arist. Pol. 1295b6 : c. gen. (cf. πείθω B. I.3), ἐπιταγμάτων Epist. Darei in SIG 22.7 (v B. C.) ; στρατηγοῦ OGI 12.11 ( Priene, iii B. C.), cf. 244.38 ( Syria, ii B. C.) ; τινος PGiss. 2.16 (ii B. C.) :— Med., ἔθνος . . πειθαρχέεσθαι ἑτοῖμον Hdt. 5.91.

definition: πειθάρχησις, εως, ἡ, = sq., Eustr. in EN 118.10.

obeying readily, Arist. EN 1102b31 ; τοῖς νόμοις Id. Metaph. 1061a25.
obedient, π. φρήν A. Pers. 374.
persuaded, obedient, Nonn. D. 24.171, 34.92, al. ; μῦθος ib. 8.165.

Util. 2.90b ; στράτευμα well-disciplined, Onos. 10.9 ; ψυχή Hierocl. in CA 16p.456M. ; τὸ π. submissiveness, docility, Plu. Virt.mor. 2.442c. Adv. -ίως ib. Cons.Apoll. 102e, Ph. 1.184; in Surgery, gently, Herod.Med. ap. Orib. 10.18.15, Sor. 1.70b, 2.10.
