pellis, ῥάπτω) sewing skins together, Gloss.

definition: πελλός ή, όν, (or πέλλος, η, ον, the accent varies in codd.)

children.definition: dark-coloured, dusky, πελλὴ μηκάς dub. in S. Fr. 509 ; πελλὰ ὄϊς Theoc. 5.99, cf. S. Fr. 114 ; βοῦς EM 659.38 ; πελλὸς ἐρῳδιός Arist. HA 609b22 ; π. σποδός cj. in Phoen. 1.24 ; = Lat. pullus, [ ἱμάτιον] IG 14.644 ( Supp.Epigr. 4.70, Western Locr.) ; Sicyonian for κιρρός, Zenod. ap. Gal. 19.129. (Cf. πελιός, πελιδνός, πολιός ; Skt. palitás ‘grey’, Lat. palleo, pullus.)
sock or bandage worn by runners on the ankle, A. Fr. 259, S. Fr. 1080 ; πελλασταί, πελλύτα, πελλύτεμα, are corrupt in Hsch. (Perh. fr. πεδ- F λῡτρα ‘foot-wrapper’, cf. πούς, ἔλυτρον.
sole of the foot, Hippon ap. Meno Iatr. 11.30, LXX Es. 4.17 ( 13.13), PMag.Par. 1.320, Ael. NA 14.3, Artem. 5.81 ; of camels, Hdn. 4.15.3 ; but τὰ π. τῶν δακτύλων finger- tips, Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.46.
sole of the shoe, Hp. Mochl. 32, Aen.Tact. 31.4, Herod. 7.116, Nic. Fr. 85.6, Plb. 12.6.4 ; συάγρεα πέλματα PCair.Zen. 692.18 (iii B. C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: stalk of apples and pears, Gp. 10.25.1.
scrape the sole of the foot, Et.Havn. ap. Gaisf.ad EM s.v. πέλμα.

children.label: II
children.definition: sole boots, PMasp. 5.18 (vi A.D.).
become worn in the sole, prob. in Phot., Suid. s.v. πεπελτωμένα (due to misreading of LXX Jo. 9.5).
the Peloponnesus, h.Ap. 250, Hermipp. 45, etc. ;
οἱ Πελοποννήσιοι, Hdt. 2.171, etc. ; ὄνομα Πελοποννήσιον Aen.Tact. 27.1 :
Adj., ὁ Πελοποννησιακὸς πόλεμος Str. 13.1.39, D.S. 13.24 (also ὁ Πελοποννήσιος π. Paus. 4.6.1) ; τὰ Πελοποννησιακά Str. 14.2.9 :
Adv., Πελοποννᾱσιστὶ λαλεῖν talk in the Peloponnesian, i.e. Dorian, dialect, Theoc. 15.92.
Pelops, Il. 2.104, etc. : Adj. Πελόπιος, E. Fr. 515, etc. ; Πελοπήϊος, A. R. 1.758, al. : pecul. fem. Πελοπηΐς, ΐδος, Call. Del. 72, A.R. 4.1570, Nic. Fr. 104.
serve as a πελταστής, opp. ὁπλιτεύω, X. An. 5.8.5, Vect. 4.52, App. BC 2.70.

definition: πελτάριον [ ᾰ], τό, Dim. of πέλτη, Callix. 2, Luc. Bacch. 1.

children.definition: one who bears a light shield ( πέλτη), targeteer, E. Rh. 311, Th. 2.29, Lys. 19.21, X. Cyr. 2.1.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: light troops, Id. HG 4.4.16, IG 1(2).97.17, 99.5, etc.
skilled in the use of the πέλτη, Pl. Tht. 165d ; οἱ π. Id. Prt. 350a :

senses.definition: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) tactics of a targeteer, Id. Lg. 813e ;
τὸ -κόν, = οἱ πελτασταί, X. An. 7.6.29, etc.
Adv. Sup. πελταστικώτατα in the best manner of πελτασταί, Id. Oec. 21.7.

children.definition: small light shield of leather without a rim, orig. Thracian, Hdt. 7.75 ; Θρῃκίας π. ἄναξ E. Alc. 498, cf. Ba. 783, Ar. Lys. 563, IG 1(2).282.120, PCair.Zen. 14 (b) 12 (iii B. C.), etc. ; π. Ἀμαζονική Plu. Pomp. 35.
body of πελτασταί, E. Rh. 410.
horseʼs ornament, ib. 305.

children.label: II
children.definition: shaft, pole, X. An. 1.10.12 : expld. by δόρυ, ἁκόντιον, Hsch., by λόγχη, Suid.
the Nile-fish κορακῖνος salted, Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 3.121b.
Luc. DMort. 25[12].2.
Dim. of πέλτη II, Men. Pk. 202.
platform for a sarcophagus, Supp.Epigr. 6.307,428,434 ( Lycaonia) ; cf. πλάτας, πλάτος (B).

definition: πελτοφόρος ( Boeot. πελτ-φόρας IG 7.210 ( Aegosthena), 2823 ( Hyettos), also πελταφόρας, Supp.Epigr. 3.354 ( Thisbe, iii B.C.)), ον, ( πέλτη)

children.definition: bearing a target, [ Arist.] Pepl. 30 ; οἱ π., = πελτασταί, X. Cyr. 7.1.24, etc. ; π. ἱππεῖς light horse, Plb. 3.43.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: axe, LXX Je. 23.29, Babr. 64.9 (with ῡ), Ath. 9.392b, PHamb. 10.40 (ii A.D.) ; rejected as barbarous by Phot. s.v. πέλεκυς :— Dim. πελύκιον, τό, Peripl.M.Rubr. 6,17, PRyl. 393v 15 (ii/iii A. D.).

definition: Πελυσιών, ῶνος, ὁ, name of month at Samos, SIG 976.56 (ii B. C.).

πέλω and πέλομαι, only pres., impf., and aor. :— Act., mostly 3 sg. πέλει, Il. 9.134, Sol. 13.16, Pi. P. 4.145 (s.v.l.), A. Ch. 534 ; 1 sg. πέλω S. OT 245 ; 2 sg. πέλεις Nonn. D. 44.193 ; 3 pl. πέλουσι AP 7.56, Dor. πέλοντι Pi. O. 6.100 : impf. πέλεν Il. 8.64, Hes. Sc. 164, Ar. Pax 1276 (hex.), ἔπλεν Il. 12.11, ἔπελεν Pempel. ap. Stob. 4.25.52 ; rarely in other persons, ἔπελες, πέλες, Pi. O. 1.46, Q. S. 3.564 ; Aeol. 1 pl. πέλομες Theoc. 29.27 (s. v. l.) ; imper. πέλε A. R. 1.304; subj. πέλω A. Supp. 340, πέλῃ Theoc. 28.22 ; opt. πέλοι Pi. P. 1.56, A. Pers. 526, etc. ; inf. πέλειν Id. Supp. 620, 801, Ch. 304 ; Ep. πελέναι (v.l. πελέμεν) Parm. 8.45 ; Part. πέλουσα A. Pr. 896 (lyr.) :—more freq. in Med. in same sense, πέλει Id. Eu. 149 (lyr.), 199, πέλεται Il. 11.392, Alc. 26, 49, etc., πελόμεσθα Theoc. 13.4, πέλεσθε A.R. 2.643, πέλονται Il. 10.351, S. Aj. 159 (anap.), Archyt. ap. Stob. 3.1.106 (nisi leg. πέλοντι) : impf. 3 pl. πέλοντο Il. 9.526 : aor. (always augmented) ἔπλεο 1.418, etc. ; contr. ἔπλευ 9.54, etc. ; ἔπλετο 22.116, Hes. Th. 836, Sapph. 94.26 L.-P., Emp. 21.2, B. 1.31 ; Ion. Iterat. πελέσκεο Il. 22.433, πελέσκετο Hes. Fr. 14.4, Antim. Col. 3 P. ; imper. πέλευ Il. 24.219, πελέσθω A.R. 1.1320; subj. πέληται, -ώμεθα, -ωνται, Il. 3.287, 6.358, 16.128 ; opt. πέλοιτο 22.443, A. Ag. 255 (lyr.) ; inf. πέλεσθαι A.R. 1.160 ; part. πελόμενος A. Supp. 123, 810, πλόμενος Euph. 58 (as Hom. in the compds. ἐπιπλόμενος, περιπλόμενος). —

children.definition: Aeol., Dor., and Ion. Prose, Pittac. ap. D. L. 1.81, Archyt. l.c., Aret. CA 1.4 :— come into existence, become, be :

children.label: A
children.definition: Subst. Verb, οὐ γάρ τις πρῆξις πέλεται . . γόοιο Il. 24.524 ; ὀδόντων καναχὴ πέλεν 19.365 ; ἠΰτε περ κλαγγὴ γεράνων πέλει οὐρανόθι πρό 3.3 ; εὐχωλὴ πέλεν ἀνδρῶν 4.450 ; ἄθλων, οἶά τε πολλὰ μετʼ ἀνθρώποισι πέλονται Od. 8.160 ; τιμὴν . . ἥ τε καὶ ἐσσομένοισι μετʼ ἀνθρώποισι πέληται Il. 3.287 ; ὅτε δὴ Πυλίων καὶ Ἐπειῶν ἔπλετο νεῖκος 11.737 ; τῷ δʼ ἤδη δεκάτη . . πέλεν ἠὼς οἰχομένῳ it was the tenth day since his departure, Od. 19.192 ; γαλήνη ἔπλετο νηνεμίη 5.392 ; ἂν κῦδος Ἀχαιῶν ἔπλετο Il. 13.677, cf. Od. 4.441 ; σέο δʼ ἐκ τάδε πάντα πέλονται Il. 13.632 ; τοῦ δʼ ἐξ ἀργύρεος ῥυμὸς πέλεν 5.729 ; ἐν δὲ γυνὴ . . πέλεν Od. 24.211 ; τὰ δʼ ὀλοὰ πελόμενʼ οὐ παρέρχεται when once in being they pass not away, A. Th. 768 (lyr.), cf. Supp. 123, 810 (both lyr.).

data.quote: οὐ γάρ τις πρῆξις πέλεται . . γόοιο
ἠΰτε περ κλαγγὴ γεράνων πέλει οὐρανόθι πρό
ἄθλων, οἶά τε πολλὰ μετʼ ἀνθρώποισι πέλονται
τιμὴν . . ἥ τε καὶ ἐσσομένοισι μετʼ ἀνθρώποισι πέληται
ὅτε δὴ Πυλίων καὶ Ἐπειῶν ἔπλετο νεῖκος
σέο δʼ ἐκ τάδε πάντα πέλονται
τοῦ δʼ ἐξ ἀργύρεος ῥυμὸς πέλεν

children.definition: become, αἶψά τέ οἱ δῶ ἀφνειὸν πέλεται Od. 1.393, cf. Il. 24.219 ; λύκων ἤϊα πέλονται 13.103 ; ἀπὸ κροτάφων πελόμεσθα πάντες γηραλέοι Theoc. 14.68 ; ἦ τʼ ἄλλως ὑπʼ ἐμεῖο . . ὀξὺ βέλος πέλεται quite otherwise does my spear become sharp, i. e. in a very different way does my (emphat.) spear prove its edge, Il. 11.392, cf. A. Ag. 392 (lyr.).

data.quote: αἶψά τέ οἱ δῶ ἀφνειὸν πέλεται

children.definition: be, οὐ μέν πως ἅλιον πέλει ὅρκιον Il. 4.158 ; τριηκόσιοί τε καὶ ἑξήκοντα πέλοντο Od. 14.20 ; ὅσσον τʼ ἐν νειῷ οὖρον πέλει ἡμιόνοιιν 8.124, cf. Il. 10.351, 23.431 ; ῥεῖά τʼ ἀριγνώτη πέλεται Od. 6.108 ; ὀξύτατον πέλεται φάος Il. 14.345, cf. A. Ag. 1124 (lyr.), Eu. 233, S. Ant. 333 (lyr.), E. Med. 520, etc.—In Lesbian verse the Copula, which is usu. omitted, is sts. expressed by πέλεται and πέλονται, as Sapph. 101.

data.quote: οὐ μέν πως ἅλιον πέλει ὅρκιον
ὅσσον τʼ ἐν νειῷ οὖρον πέλει ἡμιόνοιιν

children.definition: aor., to have become : hence, to be, τίς . . ὅμιλος ὅδʼ ἔπλετο; what gathering is this? Od. 1.225 ; ἔρξον ὅπως ἐθέλεις καί τοι φίλον ἔπλετο θυμῷ 13.145 ; ἔνθα μάλιστα ἀμβατός ἐστιπόλις καὶ ἐπίδρομον ἔπλετο τεῖχος Il. 6.434 : with part., λελασμένος ἔπλευ 23.69 ; ὀϊζυρὸς περὶ πάντων ἔπλεο 1.418 (so as Subst. Verb, Od. 2.364) ; in similes, Il. 2.480, 8.556. ( πελ- fr. qṷel-ʼturn’, cf. τέλομαι, πόλος, ἀμφι-, ἐπι-, περι-πέλομαι, also ἐπιτέλλω (B), περιτέλλομαι, Skt. cárati ‘move’ ; for the sense cf. Germ. werden , cogn. with Lat. verto.)

data.quote: ἔρξον ὅπως ἐθέλεις καί τοι φίλον ἔπλετο θυμῷ
ἔνθα μάλιστα ἀμβατός ἐστιπόλις καὶ ἐπίδρομον ἔπλετο τεῖχος

definition: πελώϊος, gen. sg., dub. sens. in PAmh. 56.7 (ii B. C.).

children.definition: portent, prodigy, monster, Ep. Noun, only nom. and acc., in early writers always of living beings, mostly in bad sense, as of the Cyclops, π. ἀθεμίστια εἰδώς Od. 9.428 ; αὐτὴ δʼ αὖτε π. κακόν, of Scylla, 12.87 ; of the serpent Python, h.Ap. 374 ; of a dolphin, π. μέγα τε δεινόν τε ib. 401 ; even of Hephaestus, π. αἴητον ἀνέστη χωλεύων Il. 18.410 ; later, of things, εὐρυτενὴς ὠγκοῦτο π. μίτος Nonn. D. 24.257.—Cf. πέλωρος.
Archestr. Fr. 56.4, cf. AP 6.224 ( Theodorid.), Nic. Fr. 83.

definition: πελώριος (also τελώριος (q. v.)), ον, fem. (not in Hom.) - ιος Hes. Th. 179, - ίη A.R. 4.1682 :

children.definition: Hom., mostly of gods, Ἀΐδης, Ἄρης, Il. 5.395, 7.208 ; or heroes, as Αἴας, Ἕκτωρ, Ἀχιλεύς, 3.229, 11.820, 21.527 ; Ὠρίων Od. 11.572 ; ἀνὴρ π., of Polyphemus, 9.187, cf. Il. 3.166, Pi. O. 7.15 ; also of things, ἔγχος, τεύχεα, Il. 8.424, 10.439 ; λᾶας Od. 11.594 ; κύματα 3.290 ; ἅρπη Hes. Th. 179 ; κλέος Pi. O. 10(11).21 : rare in Trag. (only lyr.), γᾶς π. τέρας, of a dragon, E. IT 1248 (lyr.) ; τὰ πρὶν π. the mighty things, or mighty ones, of old, A. Pr. 151 (lyr.) ; used by Com. in mock-heroic style, Ar. Av. 321 ; in exaggerated language, Arist. Rh. 1408b13: in later Prose, Ath. 3.84e.
π. (sc. ἱερά), τά, a harvest-festival, celebrated in honour of Zeus in Thessaly, Bato Sinop. 4 ; Πελώριος, epith. of Zeus, Q.S. 11.273.
mussel, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.52 and 97, Alciphr. 1.2 ; π. κόγχη Ath. 1.4c.

Gorgon, Il. 5.741, Od. 11.634 ; of the offspring of the earth, Hes. Th. 295, cf. 845, 856 ; of a large stag, Od. 10.168 ; of the enchanted animals of Circe, ib. 219 ; πέλωρα θεῶν portents sent by the gods, Il. 2.321.—Prop. neut. from sq.

definition: πέλωρος, η, ον, also ος, ον Od. 15.161 (the only example of the fem. in Hom.) :—

children.definition: monstrous, prodigious, huge, with collat. notion of terrible, in Hom. much rarer than the form πελώριος, but in Hes. the more common ; δράκοντα φέρων ὀνύχεσσι πέλωρον Il. 12.202 ; χῆνα φ. ὀ. π. Od. l.c. ; π. ὄφιν, δεινόν τε μέγαν τε. Hes. Th. 299 ; Γαῖα πελώρη ib. 159, 173, Q.S. 2.225 ; θάμβος Maiist. 55 ; ὡς φοβερός, ὡς π. Ezek. Exag. 125 : neut. pl. as Adv., πέλωρα βιβᾷ with gigantic tread, h.Merc. 225, cf. 349 : Sup. πελώριστος Theoc. Ep. 18.5 (fort. πεδωρισταί = Μεθορισταί ( Dor. ὦρος = ὅρος), i.e. μέτοικοι).
tax paid by millers, PRyl. 167.20 (i A. D.), POxy. 2128.10 (ii A. D.), etc.
any kind of dressed food: mostly in pl., pastry, cakes, sweetmeats, Stesich. 2, Panyas. 26, Hdt. 1.160, Antiph. 174.2; Ἀττικὰ π. Pl. R. 404d.
small cake, Ath. 14.645e.
discoursing of cakes, Ath. 14.648a.
pastrycook, Luc. Sat. 13.
commander of a body of five, X. Cyr. 2.1.23 (v.l. πενταδαρχῶν), Eq.Mag. 4.9 (v.l. -άρχης( :

definition: πεμπαδάρχης, ου, ὁ, Hsch. s.v. δωδεκάδαρχοι (pl.).

children.definition: five-fold, Dam. Pr. 264.

count on the five fingers, i.e. count by fives, and then, generally, count, A. Eu. 748, Thphr. Char. 23.2 (cj.), A.R. 2.975, Plu. E apud Delph. 2.387e, etc.:— Med., ἐπὴν πάσας πεμπάσσεται ( Ep. aor.1 subj.) when he has done counting them all, Od. 4.412.

children.label: II
children.definition: count up, reckon over, θεοπροπίας θυμῷ π. A.R. 4.1748 :— Med., πάντα νόῳ πεμπάσσατο ib. 350.—In Prose ἀναπεμπάζω is more common. ( Aeol. acc. to EM 660.4.)
IG 5(1).222 ( Sparta).
Pi. O. 5.6 (prob.), Inscr.Cypr. 134 H.
the number five, Pl. R. 546c, Phd. 104a ( πεμπτάς codd.), Plu. E apud Delph. 2.387e, Plot. 6.3.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: group of five, X. Cyr. 2.1.22 and 24, HG 7.2.6, Dam. Pr. 203; cf. πεντάς.

children.label: III
children.definition: fifth part, SIG 57.35,39 (Milet., V B.C.).
one who counts: as a Verbal c. acc., μύρια π. reviewing by tens of thousands, A. Pers. 980 (lyr.).
Hdt. Vit.Hom. 37; gen. πέμπων Alc. 33.7: πεμπεκαιδέκοτος, Aeol. for πεντεκαιδέκατος, IG 12(2).82.5 (Mytil.).
made of five ox-hides, σάμβαλα Sapph. 98 ( πενταβόεια codd. Heph.).
aged, Lyc. 682, 826, Gal. 6.380, Choerob. in Theod. 1.357 H. (alternatively expld. as = στωμύλος, λάλος by Hsch.).
IG 5(2).33.13 ( Tegea, iii B.C.).
on the fifth day, Thd. Ex. 13.18.

on the fifth day, mostly agreeing with the Subject, π. ἱκόμεσθα on the fifth day we came, Od. 14.257, cf. Hp. Aph. 4.36; π. γεγενημένος born five days before, Pi. O. 6.53; πεμπταῖα λογίζομαι . . γενέσθαι D. 19.59; προκεῖσθαι π. to have been five days laid out as dead, Ar. Av. 474; [νεκροὶ] ἤδη ἦσαν π. X. An. 6.4.9; ἔκρινεν [ὁ πυρετὸς] πεμπταίοισι came to a crisis with those who had had it five days, Hp. Epid. 1.20; π. ἀπὸ τῆς νίκης, ἐκ γενετῆς, Plu. Fab. 17, Luc. Halc. 5.

children.label: II
children.definition: every fifth day, π. πυρετοί quintan fevers, Hp. Epid. 1.24, cf. Alex.Aphr. Pr. 2.10; ποτισμοί POxy. 729.24 (ii A.D.).
five times, D.C. 53.16.
to be sent, Luc. Phal. 1.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: πεμπτέον, one must send, X. Cyr. 8.1.11.
fifth part, Hp. Nat.Mul. 50, Pl. Lg. 956c.
S. Fr. 142 ii 10 (lyr.).

fifth : with four others, πέμπτος μετὰ τοῖσιν Od. 9.335; π. αὐτός Th. 1.61, 3.19; π. σπιθαμή, i.e. four cubits and a span, Hdt. 2.106; ἐς π. μῆνα by the fifth month, Id. 1.77; τὸ πέμπτον μέρος a fifth, Pl. Ap. 36b, etc.; τὸ π., as Adv., for the fifth time, ὕπατοι, ὑπατεύων, D.S. 19.77, Plu. Fab. 19.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἡ πέμπτη (sc. ἡμέρα) the fifth day, Hes. Op. 802, 803, Ar. Nu. 1131.

children.label: b
children.definition: ἡ π. (sc. ὥρα) the fifth hour, Arr. Epict. 1.1.29.
ἡ π. (sc. ὁδός), in the Roman camp, = via quintana, Plb. 6.30.6.
ἡ π. tax of one-fifth, PLond. 3.1107.5, al. (iii A.D.).

children.label: III
children.definition: τὸ π. σῶμα the fifth or celestial element, Philol. 12, Placit. 1.3.22; called π. στοιχεῖον ib. 2.6.2; π. οὐσία ib. 2.25.7, Phlp. in Ph. 9.29.
sent, ἀπὸ τῶν τετρακοσίων π. πρέσβεις f.l. in Th. 8.86.

definition: πέμπω, Ep. inf. -έμεναι, -έμεν, Od. 13.48, 10.18 : Ion. impf. πέμπεσκε Hdt. 7.106 : fut. πέμψω Od. 5.167, etc.; Dor. πεμψῶ Theoc. 5.141; Ep. inf. πεμψέμεναι Od. 10.484: aor. ἔπεμψα, Ep. πέμψα Il. 1.442, 21.43, etc.: pf. πέπομφα Th. 7.12, X. Cyr. 6.2.10, D. 4.48 : plpf. ἐπεμπόμφει, Ion. -εε, X. Cyr. 6.2.9, Hdt. 1.85 :— Med. (not in early Prose, exc. in compds. ἀπο-, μετα-, προ-πέμπομαι), fut. πέμψομαι only f.l. in E. Or. 111 : aor. ἐπεμψάμην Id. Hec. 977 :— Pass., fut. πεμφθήσομαι Str. 1.1.4, Plu. Demetr. 27 : aor. ἐπέμφθην Pi. N. 3.59, S. El. 1163, etc.: 3 sg. pf. πέπεμπται A. Th. 473, ( προ-) Th. 7.77; part. πεπεμμένος D. 23.159, Luc. Alex. 32, D.C. 50.13: plpf. ἐπέπεμπτο Id. 36.18, ( προὐπ-) Th. 8.79 (cj.) :—

children.definition: send, freq. of persons, as messengers, spies, etc., Il. 3.116, A. Th. 37, Hdt. 7.15, etc.; of troops, A. Pers. 34 (anap.), Th. 470 : c. dupl. acc., ὁδὸν π. τινά send one on a journey, S. Aj. 739, cf. El. 1163 ( Pass.); also of things, πέμψω δέ τοι οὖρον ὄπισθεν Od. 5.167, etc.; π. γράμματα, ἐπιστολήν, Pl. Ep. 310d, 323b; in letters, in the epistolary aorist, Th. 1.129, X. An. 1.9.25, LXX 2 Es. 4.14; π. κακόν τινι send one evil, Il. 15.109; π. παραβᾶσιν Ἐρινύν A. Ag. 59 (anap.); ποινάς, ζημίαν, Id. Eu. 203 (dub.), E. Fr. 506; ψόφον π. ἔσω Id. IT 1308; ὕπνον, ὀνείρατα, S. Ph. 19, El. 460; freq. of omens, π. οἰωνόν, τέρατα, Il. 24.310, X. Mem. 1.4.15, cf. Smp. 4.48; μαντείας S. OT 149; also ἱκεσίους π. λιτάς Id. Ph. 495 ; π. ἀρωγάς, ἀλκάν, A. Eu. 598, S. OT 189 (lyr.) :—Constr.:

π. τινὰ Θήβας, ἀγρούς, Id. OC 1770 (anap.), OT 761 : also c. dat., Ἀΐδᾳ E. IT 159 (anap.): but usu. with Preps., ἐς Τροίην, φίλην ἐς πατρίδα γαῖαν, etc., Il. 6.207, Od. 5.37, etc.; π. εἰς Ἀΐδαο Il. 21.48 ; δόμον Ἄϊδος εἴσω Od. 9.524; π. εἰς διδασκάλων send to school, Pl. Prt. 325d (so πέμπειν alone, Ar. Fr. 216); π. ἐπʼ εὐρέα νῶτα θαλάσσης over. . , Od. 4.560, etc. ; π.ἐπὶ Θρῃκῶν ἵππους to them, Il. 10.464; but πέμπειν ἐπί τι send for a purpose, ἐπʼ ὕδωρ Hdt. 5.12 ; ἐπὶ κατασκοπήν X. Cyr. 6.2.9 ( π. εἰς κ. S. Ph. 45); π. ἀρωγὴν ἐπὶ νίκην A. Ch. 477 codd. (anap.); π. ἐπί τινι send to him, Il. 2.6; against. . , A. Ag. 61 (anap.), etc.; for a purpose, ἐπὶ πολέμῳ X. HG 4.8.17; περί τινος about something, Th. 1.91, X. Cyr. 6.2.10; ὑπέρ τινος Epist. Philipp. ap. D. 12.12; παρά or πρός τινα to some one, Th. 2.81, X. An. 5.2.6; ὥς τινα Th. 8.50.
οἴκαδε, οἶκόνδε, Od. 19.281, 24.418; ὅνδε δόμονδε Il. 16.445; θύραζε Od. 9.461; πόλεμόνδε Il. 18.452, etc.; ἕταρον γὰρ . . πέμπʼ Ἄϊδόσδε was conducting or convoying Patroclus to Hades, 23.137.

inf. of purpose, τὴν . . ἅρμασι π. νέεσθαι Od. 4.8 ; ἕπεσθαι Il. 16.575 ; ἰέναι Od. 14.396 ; ἱκανέμεν 4.29 ; ἄγειν 24.419; φέρειν Il. 16.454 ; φέρεσθαι ib. 681 ; μήτηρ με πέμπει πατρὶ τυμβεῦσαι χοάς S. El. 406 ; send word, πέμπεις . . σῇ δάμαρτι, παῖδα σὴν δεῦρʼ ἀποστέλλειν E. IA 360 ; πέμπουσιν οἱ ἔφοροι . . στρατεύεσθαι sent him orders to march, X. HG 3.1.7 : also c. part., κήρυκας π. ἀγγέλλοντας IG 1(2).76.22 : the place from which is expressed by ἀπό or ἐκ, Il. 16.447, Od. 11.635, etc.

data.quote: μήτηρ με πέμπει πατρὶ τυμβεῦσαι χοάς
πέμπεις . . σῇ δάμαρτι, παῖδα σὴν δεῦρʼ ἀποστέλλειν

children.definition: ἐπέμψαμεν πρὸς ὑμᾶς περὶ ἀποστάσεως Th. 3.13 ; πέμπει κελεύων Th. 1.91, 2.81; ἐκέλευε . . πέμπων X. An. 2.3.1 ; ἔπεμπε πρὸς Κῦρον δεόμενος Id. Cyr. 1.5.4 ; ἔπεμπον ἐρωτῶντες Id. An. 6.6.4, etc.
send forward, nominate a person for a post, ὀνόματα Wilcken Chr. 28.20 (ii A.D.) :— Pass., ib. 392.7 (ii A.D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: send forth or away, dismiss, send home, τὸν ξεῖνον Od. 7.227, al.: less freq. in Il., as 24.780; χρὴ ξεῖνον παρεόντα φιλεῖν, ἐθέλοντα δὲ πέμπειν ‘welcome the coming, speed the parting guest’, Od. 15.74 ; ὑπέδεκτο καὶ πέμπε 23.315 ; of the father who sends off his daughter to go to her husband, c. dat., 4.5 ; π. τινὰ ἄποικον S. OT 1518, etc.
discharge, shoot, πέτρας Hes. Th. 716 : metaph., ὄμματος . . τόξευμα A. Supp. 1005 : abs., οἱ πολλάκις πέμποντες ἔστιν ὅτε τυγχάνουσι τοῦ σκοποῦ Eun. VS p.495 B.

data.quote: οἱ πολλάκις πέμποντες ἔστιν ὅτε τυγχάνουσι τοῦ σκοποῦ

children.definition: send forth, utter, A. Th. 443, S. Ph. 846 (lyr.), 1445 (anap.).

children.label: III
children.definition: conduct, escort, Il. 1.390, Od. 14.336, S. Tr. 571, etc.; freq. of Hermes and other gods, Od. 11.626, A. Eu. 12, Supp. 219; ὁ πέμπων abs., of Hermes, S. Ph. 133 (cf. πομπός, πομπαῖος, etc.); of a ship, convey, carry, Od. 8.556, cf. A. Supp. 136 (lyr.); κραιπνοφόροι δέ μʼ ἔπεμψαν αὖραι Id. Pr. 132 (lyr.), cf. Pi. P. 4.203 ( Pass.).

πομπὴν π. conduct, or take part in, a procession, Hdt. 5.56, Ar. Ec. 757, Th. 6.56, Lys. 13.80, D. 4.26, etc.; π. χορούς move in dancing procession, E. El. 434 (lyr.); Παναθήναια π. Men. 494, Philostr. VA 4.22 :— Pass., φαλλὸς Διονύσῳ πεμπόμενος carried in procession in his honour, Hdt. 2.49, cf. Plu. Aem. 32, Demetr. 12; τῆς πομπῆς ὅπως ἂν ὡς κάλλισταπεμφθῇ IG 1(2).84.27; χορὸς ὁ εἰς Δῆλον πεμπόμενος X. Mem. 3.3.12.

data.quote: τῆς πομπῆς ὅπως ἂν ὡς κάλλισταπεμφθῇ

children.label: IV
children.definition: send as a present, εἵματα, σῖτον, Od. 16.83, 4.623; π. δῶρα, σκῦλα, ξένια, Hdt. 7.106 ( Act. and Pass.), S. Ph. 1429, X. Cyr. 3.1.42.

children.label: V
children.definition: send up, produce, ὅσα πέμπει βιόδωρος αἶα S. Ph. 1162 (lyr.).

children.label: B
children.definition: Med., πέμπεσθαί τινα send for one, S. OC 602, ubiv. Sch.; τί χρῆμʼ ἐπέμψω τὸν ἐμὸν ἐκ δόμων πόδα; E. Hec. 977.

children.label: II
children.definition: send in oneʼs own service or cause to be sent, S. OT 556, Luc. Tox. 14.
five-pronged fork, Il. 1.463, Od. 3.460, cf. Ps.- Hdt. Vit.Hom. 37.
fish, Numen. ap. Ath. 7.309f.
accompanied by vesicular eruption, Hp. Epid. 6.1.14, cf. Gal. ad loc. (17(1).878), Id. 19.399; πεμφιδ-, Hsch.
breath, blast, ἀπῇξε πέμφιξ Ἰονίου πέλας πόρου prob. in S. Fr. 337; κεραυνία π. βροντῆς Id. Fr. 538; δυσχείμερος π. A. Fr. 195.4.
ray, τηλέσκοπον πέμφιγα χρυσέαν ἰδών S. Fr. 338 ; ἂς οὔτε π. ἡλίου προσδέρκεται οὔτε κτλ. A. Fr. 170.
drop, Id. Fr. 205; μηδʼ αἵματος πέμφιγα πρὸς πέδῳ βάλῃς Id. Fr. 183.

data.quote: μηδʼ αἵματος πέμφιγα πρὸς πέδῳ βάλῃς

children.definition: cloud, πέμφιγι . . ἀγγέλῳ πυρός cloud, harbinger of lightning, S. Fr. 539 ; driving rain or rain-cloud, Ibyc. 17; πελιδναὶ φλύκταιναι πέμφιξιν ἐειδόμεναι ὑετοῖο, . . ἀμυδρήεσσαι ἐς ὠπήν livid pustules like rain clouds (in colour) . . dim to the sight, Nic. Th. 273 (but = bubbles acc. to Sch.); dub. sens. in Call. Fr. 483 (prob. = Oxy. 2080.43).
ghost, Lyc. 1106, and so prob. in Euph. 134.
pustule or part surrounding a pustule, ἐφίσταται π. οἷον ἐλαίου χλωρῆς ὥσπερ ἀράχνιον Euryphon ap. Gal. 17 (1).886.
= foreg. 5, Lyc. 686 (v.l. πεμφίγων).
wasp that builds in hollow oaks, Nic. Al. 183 (cf. Sch.), Th. 812 ; cf. τενθρηδών, ἀνθρηδών.
sending, mission, Hdt. 8.54 ; ἡ π. τῶν νεῶν Th. 7.17; ἐπιστολῶν πέμψεις Aen. Tact. 31.1, cf. Arist. Po. 1452b6; ἡ π. τῶννικητηρίων, of a triumphal procession, D.C. 44.41 ( μέμψιν codd.).
the class of serfs, Arist. Pol. 1264a35 (pl.), 1269a37.

definition: πενέστερος, πενέστ-ατος, Comp. and Sup. of πένης.
πενέστης, ου, ὁ, ( πένομαι, cf. D.H. 2.9)

children.definition: labourer, mostly in pl., of the Thessalian serfs, Theopomp.Com. 75, X. HG 2.3.36, 6.1.11, D. 23.199, Arist. Fr. 586, Theoc. 16.35 (cf. Sch. ad loc.), Philocrat. ap. Ath. 6.264a, Archemach. 1.

children.label: II
children.definition: slave, bondsman, τινος E. Heracl. 639; π. ἁμὸς ἀρχαίων δόμων Id. Fr. 830; labourer, poor man, Ar. V. 1273 (lyr.), Timo 39, AP 6.300 ( Leon.).
in the state of a πενέστης, τὸ Θετταλῶν π. ἔθνος the caste of serfs, Pl. Lg. 776d.
to be poor, Hsch.: aor. part. Pass. πενηθείς LXX Pr. 24.32 ( 30.9).

one who works for his living, day-labourer, poor man, opp. πλούσιος, Democr. 283; opp. δυνάμενος, Archyt. 3; πτωχοῦ μὲν γὰρ βίος . . , ζῆν ἐστιν μηδὲν ἔχοντα· τοῦ δὲ πένητος ζῆν φειδόμενον καὶ τοῖς ἔργοις προσέχοντα Ar. Pl. 553 ; οἱ π. αὐτῶν Hdt. 1.133, 2.47 ; πλούσιος ἐκ πένητος Lys. 1.4 ; πένητες ἄνθρωποι Hdt. 8.51 ; οἷʼ ἀνὴρ π. S. Ph. 584; π. ἵππος X. Oec. 11.5.

data.quote: πτωχοῦ μὲν γὰρ βίος . . , ζῆν ἐστιν μηδὲν ἔχοντα· τοῦ δὲ πένητος ζῆν φειδόμενον καὶ τοῖς ἔργοις προσέχοντα

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., π. δόμοι E. El. 1139 : c. neut., ἐν πένητι σώματι ib. 372 : c. gen., χρημάτων πένητες poor in money, ib. 38 ; π. φίλων Pl. Ep. 332c ; π. ἀπολογίας Luc. Apol. 11 : Comp. πενέστερος X. Ath. 1.13: Sup. πενέστατος D. 21.123.

definition: πένησσα, ἡ, fem. of foreg., Hsch.

children.definition: to be poor, Ps.-Phoc. 28, Crates Ep. 18, Phld. Rh. 2.172 S., Nic.Dam. 44.3 J., etc. ; π. τινός Emp. 57.3.
starveling, Cerc. 4.4.
sad, mourning, ἐστόρεσαν παλάμαις π. AP 7.604 ( Paul.Sil.) ; π. τοκῆας Supp.Epigr. 6.140.6 ( Cotiaeum); μορφᾶς εἰκὼν π. IG 3.1416.
mourned, θάνατος Supp.Epigr. 6.140.22 ( Cotiaeum).
ὄρνιθες Mosch. 3.49, cf. Nonn. D. 14.271.

definition: πένθεια, ἡ, poet. form of πένθος, A. Ag. 430 (lyr.).

children.definition: mourning, Aq., Thd. Is. 61.2.

definition: πενθερά, Ion. πενθερή, ἡ, fem. of πενθερός,

children.definition: mother-in-law, D. 45.70, Call. Dian. 149, Ev.Marc. 1.30, Plu. TG 8, etc.

brother-in-law, CIG 4079 ( Ancyra), Keil-Premerstein Erster Bericht No.137 ( Daldis), 149 ( Gordos), Zweiter Bericht No.145 (ibid.), BCH 8.382, 386 ( Lydia) :—later πενθερ-ίδης, ου, ὁ, PLond. 5.1676.8, 37 (vi A. D.).

definition: πενθερικός, ή, όν, = sq., Man. 5.297, MAMA 3.512 ( Corycus).

children.definition: of or for a πενθερός, Arat. 252.

children.label: II
children.definition: πενθέριον : τὴν προῖκα Θάσιοι, Hsch., cf. BCH 50.227 ( Thasos, ii A.D.).
Tz. ad Lyc. 161.
father-in-law, Il. 6.170, Od. 8.582, Lex Draconis ap. D. 43.57 (pl.), Hdt. 3.52, PCair.Zen. 369.2 (iii B. C.) ; λαβὼν Ἄδραστον π. S. OC 1302 : in pl., parents-in-law, E. Hipp. 636.

children.label: II
children.definition: connexion by marriage, e.g. brother-in-law, Id. El. 1286 ; also, = γαμβρός, son-in-law, S. Fr. 305 (pl.). (Cf. Skt. bándhus ‘kinsman’, Lith. beñdras ‘comrade’, Goth. bindan ‘bind’.)
slaying oneʼs father-in-law, Lyc. 161.
-κόν, τό, = πεντετηρίς II, SIG 577.70 ( Milet., iii/ii B. C.), PGrad. 6.7 (iii B. C.).
in the fifth year (inclusively), τροπαί Philod.Scarph. 131.

definition: πενθέω, Ep. 3 dual πενθείετον Il. 23.283 ; Ep. inf. πενθήμεναι Od. 18.174, 19.120 : fut. -ήσω A. Fr. 207 : aor. ἐπένθησα Id. Ch. 173, Aeschin. 3.211 : pf. πεπένθηκα Luc. Demon. 25, ( συμ-) D. 60.33 : ( πένθος) :—

children.definition: bewail, lament, esp. for persons, νέκυν πενθῆσαι Il. 19.225, cf. Trag.Adesp. 331 ; πενθέειν τινα ὡς τεθνεῶτα Hdt. 4.95 ; π. γόοις A. Pers. 545 (anap.) ; π. τινὰς δημοσίᾳ Lys. 2.66 ; π. τινὰ τριχί A. Ch. 173 ; ἐπί τινι π. καὶ κείρασθαι Aeschin. 3.211 : abs., mourn, go into mourning, Pl. Phdr. 258b, etc.: c. acc. cogn., πενθεῖ νέον οἶκτον A. Supp. 64 :— Pass., to be mourned for, Isoc. 10.27 ; πένθος ἀμφί τινι πενθεῖται Arr. Tact. 33.4.
π. κακά S. OT 1320, Lys. 2.2 ; πήματα S. OC 739; τύχας E. Med. 268.
lamentation, mourning, A. Ch. 432 (pl., lyr.), Theoc. 26.26 (with play on Πενθεύς) ; διπλοῦν πένθιμον δαιμόνων (leg. πένθημʼ ὁμαιμόνων) ἔχειν E. Supp. 1035.
five days’ labour, PLond. 2.321 ( c) 5 ( ii A. D., abbrev.), PTeb. 662 (ii A. D.).

of five days, ἀγών Sch. Pi. O. 5.13 ; κατὰ πενθήμερον for alternate periods of five days, X. HG 7.1.14 ; once in every five days, Arist. Ath. 30.4 ; also καθʼ ἑκάστην πενθήμερον SIG 364.9 ( Ephesus, iii B. C.).
two and a half ἀρτάβαι, PCair.Zen. 376.4 (iii B. C.).
two and a half γύαι, Tab.Heracl. 2.20.

consisting of five halves, i.e. of two and a half : in Prosody, τομὴ π. the caesura after two feet and a half, as in Hexam. and Iamb. Trim., Aristid. Quint. 1.25, etc.; τὸ π. (with or without μέτρον) the first two feet and a half of a verse, Quint. Inst. 9.4.78, Heph. 7.3, al., Sch. Ar. Av. 627.
consisting of five half-feet, i.e. of 2 1/2 feet, X. Oec. 19.3, 5, IG 2(2).1682.11, Milet. 7.56.
spans long, Ph. Bel. 59.11.
weighing 2 1/2 talents, Ph. Bel. 51.43.
mournful, A. Ag. 420 (lyr.).
lamenting, mourning, E. Ph. 323 codd., Tr. 141 (both lyr.).
of or for mourning, ἱμάτιον Anaxil. 37 : in later Prose, Sm. Je. 9.19(18).
mourning, Sch.rec. A. Ag. 429.
one must lament, τὸν θάνατον Ap.Ty. Ep. 58.
mourner, A. Pers. 946 (lyr.), Th. 1067 (anap.) :—fem. πενθ-ήτριᾰ, she who mourns for, κακῶν E. Hipp. 805.
of or in sign of mourning, πλόκαμος A. Ch. 7 ; βόθροι π. trenches in which mourners lay, Ion Trag. 54.

of or for mourning, mournful, ὀδυρμοί Plu. Cons.Apoll. 2.102b ; θέα Porph. Abst. 2.50 ; ἐσθής Chor. p.6B [8.1.11].; ἐν πενθικοῖς (sc. ἐσθήμασι) LXX Ex. 33.4. Adv. -κῶς, ἔχειν τινός to be in mourning for a person, X. Cyr. 5.2.7 ; πάνυ π. ἐσκευασμένη Luc. Cal. 5, cf. Plu. Cons.Apoll. 2.113d (v.l. -ητικῶς).

definition: πένθιμος, ον, also η, ον D.S. 11.57 :—

children.definition: = foreg., δακρύων π. αἰδώς A. Supp. 579 (lyr.); κουρά E. Alc. 512, Or. 458; π. πρέπεις ὁρᾶν prob. in Id. Supp. 1056 ; ἐσθής D.S. l.c.; τὰ π. mourning garments, Plu. Cons.Apoll. 2.114e, cf. D.S. 13.101.

children.label: II
children.definition: sorry, wretched, γῆρας E. Alc. 622 ; π. ὕπνον ἰαύειν, of death, Epigr.Gr. 204.7 ( Cnidus).
cause lamentation, Al. Le. 26.22.

grief, sorrow, Il. 11.658, etc.; τινος for one, Od. 18.324, etc.; π. ἄλαστον ἔχουσα Il. 24.105 ; π. λαγχάνειν S. Fr. 659 ; Τρῶας λάβε π. Il. 16.548, etc. ; μέγα π. Ἀχαιίδα γαῖαν ἱκάνει 1.254, etc.; πένθεϊ δʼ ἀτλήτῳ βεβολήατο πάντες 9.3 ; θυμὸς ἐτείρετο π. λυγρῷ 22.242, etc.

mourning, τοκεῦσι γόον καὶ π. ἔθηκας 17.37 ; παιδὸς γάρ οἱ ἄλαστον ἐνὶ φρεσὶ π. ἔκειτο Od. 24.423 ; Σάρδεσι π. παρασχών A. Pers. 322 ; δμῳαῖς προθήσειν π. οἰκεῖον στένειν S. Ant. 1249 ; π. ποιήσασθαι make a public mourning, Hdt. 2.1 ; so π. προεθήκαντο Id. 6.21 ; π. τίθεται Id. 2.46 ; π. τινὸς κοινοῦσθαι E. Alc. 426 ; ἐν πένθει [εἶναι] S. El. 290, 847 (lyr.) ; πολὺ π. ἦν κατὰ τὸ στράτευμα X. HG 4.5.10 ; π. λιπεῖν IG 3.1311 ; π. λύεσθαι, ἀποθέσθαι, Plu. Fab. 18, Alex. 75 : in pl., Pi. I. 8(7).6, Fr. 154, A. Ch. 333 (lyr.), Pl. R. 395e, Arist. Rh. 1370b25, etc.

data.quote: παιδὸς γάρ οἱ ἄλαστον ἐνὶ φρεσὶ π. ἔκειτο
πολὺ π. ἦν κατὰ τὸ στράτευμα

children.label: II
children.definition: unhappy event, misfortune, π. τινός oneʼs ill-fortune, Hdt. 3.14 ; ἔτλαν π. οὐ φατόν Pi. I. 7(6).37.

children.label: III
children.definition: a misery, S. Aj. 615 (lyr.) ; π. ἔδωκε φέρειν, i. e. the body, Epigr.Gr. 228.6 ( Ephesus). (Cf. πείσομαι from *πένθ-σομαι, fut. of πάσχω, pf. πείσονθα, Lith. kenčiù ‘suffer’, pa-kantà ‘patienceʼ; πενθ- is reduced to πṇ θ- ( παθ-) in αἰνο-παθής, etc.)

poverty, need, πενίῃ εἴκων Od. 14.157; οὐλομένην π. Hes. Op. 717; στάσις πενίας δότειρα Pi. Fr. 109.5; τῇ Ἑλλάδι π. σύντροφός ἐστι, . . [ἀρετῇ] δὲ διαχρεωμένη τὴν πενίην ἀπαμύνεται Hdt. 7.102 ; τῆς πτωχείας πενίαν φαμὲν εἶναι ἀδελφήν Ar. Pl. 549 ; π. δὲ σοφίαν ἔλαχε διὰ τὸ συγγενές (v.l. δυστυχές) E. Fr. 641 ; ἐν πενίᾳ εἶναι, γίγνεσθαι, Pl. Ap. 23c, R. 613a ; εἰς π. πολλὴν καὶ ἀπορίαν καταστῆναι And. 1.144 : pl. πενίαι Isoc. 8.128, Pl. Prt. 353d, R. 618a, etc.

data.quote: τῇ Ἑλλάδι π. σύντροφός ἐστι, . . [ἀρετῇ] δὲ διαχρεωμένη τὴν πενίην ἀπαμύνεται
τῆς πτωχείας πενίαν φαμὲν εἶναι ἀδελφήν
εἰς π. πολλὴν καὶ ἀπορίαν καταστῆναι

children.definition: lack, need, τινος Plot. 2.4.16.

children.label: II
children.definition: Πενία personified, Poverty, Alc. 92, Pl. Smp. 203b.

definition: πενιχραλέος, α, ον, collat. form of πενιχρός, AP 6.190 ( Gaet.).

children.definition: poor, needy, Od. 3.348, Alc. 49, Thgn. 165, 181, Sol. 4.23, Pi. N. 7.19.—Poet. word, found in Com., as Ar. Pl. 976, Philetaer. 4, Diod.Com. 2.8, in Pl. R. 578a, and in later Prose, as PPetr. 3p.73 (iii B. C.), Socr. ap. Stob. 3.13.64, LXX Ex. 22.25, etc.; π. δίαιτα Phld. Oec. p.48 J.: Comp. πενιχρότερος Ph. 2.284, Sup. -ότατος Plb. 6.21.7. Adv. -χρῶς Arist. Pol. 1252b3. [ ῐ by nature, Pi. and Ar. ll. cc., also Man. 2.416, elsewh. ῑ by position.]
S.E. M. 2.103, Hsch. s.v. εὐτέλεια.

definition: πένομαι, used only in pres. and impf., (cf. πενέω) :

children.label: I
children.definition: toil, work, ἀμφίπολοι . . , ἐνὶ μεγάροισι πένοντο Od. 10.348 ; περὶ δεῖπνον ἐνὶ μεγάροισι π. were busy preparing a meal, 4.624 ; ἀμφʼ αὐτὸν ἑταῖροι ἐσσυμένως ἐπένοντο Il. 24.124.

Hom., ( to have to work for oneʼs living, hence) to be poor or needy, Sol. 15, E. Hec. 1220, Th. 2.40, etc.; πλουσία ἢ πενομένη πόλις Pl. R. 577e; πλουτοῦντες ἢ π. Id. Plt. 293a; π. καὶ κάμνειν Id. Grg. 477d.

to be poor in, have need of, τῶν σοφῶν (i. e. τῆς σοφίας) A. Eu. 431 ; ὡς διαλλαγὰς ἔχοιμεν ἀλλήλοισιν ὧν πένοιτο γῆ E. Supp. 210 ; πάντων Porph. Marc. 27 ; πενόμενον τὴν ψυχὴν τῶν ἐπιβαλλόντων αὐτῇ καλῶν Hierocl. in CA 14p.451M. : c. acc., χρήματα Them. Or. (i. e. Constant. pro Them.) 22b.

data.quote: ὡς διαλλαγὰς ἔχοιμεν ἀλλήλοισιν ὧν πένοιτο γῆ
πενόμενον τὴν ψυχὴν τῶν ἐπιβαλλόντων αὐτῇ καλῶν

children.label: II
children.definition: work at, get ready, δόμον κάτα δαῖτα πένοντο Od. 2.322, cf. 3.428, etc.; ἔργα Hes. Op. 773; ὁππότε κεν δὴ ταῦτα πενώμεθα when we are a-doing this, Od. 13.394 ; τί σε χρὴ ταῦτα πένεσθαι; 24.407, cf. Il. 19.200.—On the precise meaning of πένομαι, πενία, cf. Ar. Pl. 551 sqq. (Cf. πένης, πόνος, πονηρός.)
aor. part. πενωθείς, poor, needy, v.l. for πενόμενος in Men. Mon. 43.
foot consisting of five short syllables, Choerob. in Heph. p.247C.
with five sons-in-law, νυμφεῖα Lyc. 146.
pentagram formed by Pythagoreans, Luc. Laps. 5; cf. πένταλφα.
pentagonal, σχῆμα Nicom. Ar. 2.10 ; ἀριθμός Iamb. in Nic. p.60 P. Adv. -κῶς Theo Sm. p.39 H., Iamb. in Nic. p.60 P.
pentagonwise, Nicom. Ar. 2.13.
pentagonal, Arist. Fr. 310 ; ἀριθμός, βάσις, Nicom. Ar. 2.10, 13 : πεντάγωνον, τό, pentagon, Plu. QPlat. 2.1003d, Gal. 5.67.

children.label: II
children.definition: five-pointed, five-rayed, ἀστέρες PMag.Par. 1.580.
with five fingers or toes, Arist. HA 498a34, PA 688a4.
five fingers broad, Hp. Art. 7.
= foreg. II κοχλίαι Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.85.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., = πεντέφυλλον, Dsc. 4.42.
group of five, BGU 812.2 (ii/iii A. D.).
of the weight or price of five drachmae, Hdt. 6.89 ; π. συναλλάγματα to the amount of five drachmae, Arist. Pol. 1300b33 : π., το, piece of five drachmae, Poll. 9.60 ; cf. πεντέδραχμος.
five palms long, Vitr. 2.3.3.

definition: πεντάεθλος, ον, poet. and Ion. for πένταθλος, -ον (q. v.).

children.definition: composed of five ingredients, of a remedy, Aët. 15.30.
Ar. Pax 876.
period of five years, Gloss.
falling every four ( = five inclusive) years, quinquennial, ἀγών Plu. Amat. 2.748f, IG 5(1).662 (pl., Sparta); ἄρχων ib. 14.617 ( Rhegium), cf. 741 ( Naples).
Lycurg. 102, Arist. Pol. 1308b1, Tab.Heracl. 1.105, etc.; = Lat. lustrum, Plb. 6.13.3; = quinquennalia, D.C. 54.19.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj. coming every fourth year, π. ἑορτά Pi. O. 10(11).57, N. 11.27 ; alone in same sense, Id. O. 3.21, PMich.Zen. 46.8 (iii B. C.), etc.
five years old, βοῦς Il. 2.403, 7.315 ; ὗς Od. 14.419, cf. PMasp. 5.11 (vi A. D.).

definition: πενταετής, ές, Att. πεντᾰέτης, ες (v. διέτης),

children.definition: = foreg. [πενταέτηρος] I [five years old], ἀπὸ πενταέτεος ἀρξάμενοι Hdt. 1.136 ; πενταετεῖ . . ἤθει ψυχῆς Pl. Lg. 793e :—fem. πεντᾰετίς, Plu. VOrat. 2.844a.

children.label: II
children.definition: lasting five years, σπονδαί Th. 1.112 codd. ; χρόνος IG 12(5).860.29 ( Tenos) : neut. as Adv., πεντάετες for five years, Od. 3.115.
D.H. 8.75, Plu. Per. 13, IG 7.2227 ( Thisbe), 2712.62 (Acraeph.), PFlor. 61.45 (i A. D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: the age of five, Ph. 2.276.
to be five years old, IG 14.1971.
with five girdles or zones, [ χθών] Alex.Eph. ap. Theon.Sm. p.140 H.; γῆ, οὐρανός, Str. 2.2.1, 2.5.3.
composed of five ingredients, ἀντεμβροχή Orib. Fr. 90 : πεντάθετον, τό, Aët. 15.37.
practise the πένταθλον, Xenoph. 2.2 :—also πενταθλ-έω, ib. 16, Paus. 6.14.13, Artem. 1.57.
in the πένταθλον, νίκη Sch. Pi. N. 7.9.
Arr. Epict. 3.1.5.

definition: πεντάθλιον, Lyr. πενταέθλιον, τό, = sq., πένταθλον, Pi. P. 8.66, I. 1.26.
πένταθλον, Lyr. and Ion. πεντάεθλον, τό,

children.definition: contest of the five exercises (viz. ἅλμα, ποδωκείην, δίσκον, ἄκοντα, πάλην, Simon. 153), Pi. O. 13.30, N. 7.8, B. 8.104, etc. ; πεντάεθλον ἐπασκέειν or ἀσκέειν Hdt. 6.92, 9.33 ; πένταθλʼ ἃ νομίζεται is corrupt in S. El. 691 ; cf. πέμπαθλον.

definition: πένταθλος, Lyr. and Ion. πεντάεθλος, ὁ,

children.definition: one who practises the πένταθλον or conquers therein, B. 8.27, Arist. Rh. 1361b10, Plu. QConv. 2.737f ; π. ἀνήρ Hdt. 9.75, IG 42(1).99.19 (Epid.).

children.label: II
children.definition: one who tries everything, Pl. Amat. 138e ; ἐν φιλοσοφίᾳ π. versed in every department of philosophy, D.L. 9.37 ; in depreciation, ‘jack of all trades’, X. HG 4.7.5.
five-pointed, ποδῶν ἀκμαί AP 6.57 ( Paul.Sil.).

senses.definition: GDI 1154 ( Elis), 5100.16 ( Crete), Foed. Delph. Pell. 2 A 21, IG 4.498 ( Mycenae), 7.3193 (Orchom. Boeot.).

definition: πεντακαττίς, ίδος, ἁ, Dor. for πεντηκοστύς, dub. rest. in CIG 1834 ( Issa).

children.definition: with five ways, Orac. ap. Paus. 8.9.4.
with five heads, φοῖνιξ Thphr. HP 2.6.9.
five times, Pi. N. 6.19, A. Pers. 323, Ar. Pax 242, Isoc. 5.5 :—later πεντάκῐ, Opp. C. 3.56, AP 13.15, Iamb. in Nic. p.80 P., al.
fifty thousand, Hdt. 7.103, Luc. Pisc. 20.

five thousand, Hdt. 1.194, Pl. Lg. 738a : in sg., π. ἀσπίς five thousand men-at-arms, Luc. DMeretr. 9.4 ; π. ἵππος LXX 1 Ma. 4.28 :— Dor. form πεντακιχήλιοι Abh.Berl.Akad. 1925(5).25 ( Cyrene, iii B.C.).
five-branched, π. ἡ χείρ EM 127.41.

definition: πεντακλινικός, ή, όν, = sq., σκηνὴ π. PCair.Zen. 54.34 (iii B.C.).

children.definition: with five couches, Chares 2 J., Callix. 1 ; σκηνὴ π. PSI 5.533.3 (iii B.C.) : as Subst., Arist. Mir. 842b21, PCair.Zen. 445.13 (iii B.C.).
Dsc. 4.42, Gloss.
five times truncated, Nicom. Ar. 2.14.
commander of 512 men, Ascl. Tact. 2.10, Arr. An. 7.25.6, Ael. Tact. 9.5 :—also πεντᾰκοσί-αρχος, ὁ, PPetr. 3p.4 (iii B.C.), Sammelb. 7245.2 (iii B.C.), Plu. Alex. 76.
command of 512 men, Ascl. Tact. 2.10 : pl., Arr. Tact. 10.9.
consisting of 500 δραχμαί, ἔρανος SIG 1215.6 ( Myconos).
five hundred, Od. 3.7, Hdt. 1.7, etc. : in sg., πεντακοσία ἵππος five hundred horse, Longus 3.1.

children.label: II
children.definition: οἱ π. the senate of 500, τὴν βουλὴν τοὺς π. IG 2(2).1629.243, Lycurg. 37, Aeschin. 3.2 ; ἡ βουλὴ τῶν π. D. 47.18.

possessing land which produced 500 medimni yearly, of the first class in the Solonian constitution, Th. 3.16, Lys. Fr. 207 S., Arist. Pol. 1274a19 (but attributed to Draco, Id. Ath. 4.3), Plu. Sol. 18.
five-hundredth, Lys. 26.11 : -οστή, ἡ, tax of one-fifth per cent., Ar. Ec. 1007.
company of 500, cj. for πεντηκοντύς in Sch. Od. 3.7, cf. EM 728.55.
fifth wave, supposed to be larger than the four preceding, Luc. Merc.Cond. 2 ; cf. τρικυμία.
five-oared, Gloss.
five times married, Lyc. 143.

definition: πεντάλιθα , πενταλιθίζω, dub. l. for πεντελ- in Poll. 9.126.

children.definition: weighing five λῖτραι or pounds, Poll. 4.173.

definition: πενταλκία, ἡ, a measure, GDI 4984 ( Gortyn).

children.definition: Luc. Laps. 5.
hold office for five days, Schwyzer 323 D 16 (Delph.).
consisting of five parts, χώρα Str. 3.4.19, cf. Diom. p.498 K. Adv. -ρῶς, φύλλα π. ἐπεσχισμένα Dsc. 3.48.
officials appointed for five days, AJA 19.446 ( Halae, iii B. C.).
consisting of five measures or feet, ἔπη Poll. 4.52 : π. (sc. στίχος), ὁ, pentameter, Hermesian. 7.36 : also neut. πεντάμετρον ἐλεγειακόν D.H. Comp. 25, cf. Heph. 6.2, etc.

definition: πενταμηνιαῖος, α, ον, = sq., Epigr.Gr. 344.17 ( Bithynia), Hippiatr. 20 :—also πεντα-μήνιος, BGU 859.8 (ii A.D.).

children.definition: five months old, Arist. HA 568a12 ; π. τέκνον, παιδία, five months’ child(ren), ib. 585a19, Men. Epit. 576.
consisting of five months, περίοδοι Plu. Fac.lun. 2.933e ; ὁ π. (sc. χρόνος) Hp. Epid. 3.1.ιαʹ.
= sq., σάρξ IG 12(2).498.16 ( Methymna, iii B.C.) :—also πεντά-μναος, SIG 945.9 ( Assos, iv B.C.).
weighing five minae, τυροῦ πεντάμνουν Harmod. 1, cf. IG 2(2).1013.33.
holding five modii, σκάφη Edict.Diocl. 15.48.
arc of five degrees, Paul.Al. S. 3.
of five degrees, διαστήματα Procl. Hyp. 6.9.
having five shapes, of evil, Simp. in Epict. pp. 71,72 D.
ointment, Orib. Fr. 70, Alex.Trall. 7.8 :—written πεντά-μοιρον, perh. rightly, Aët. 12.61 (v.l. -μυρον).
squadron of five vessels, Hell.Oxy. 2.4, Polyaen. 3.4.2.
a piece of five sesterces, Zonar.
measure containing five sextarii, PSI 8.881.5 (vi A. D.).
five-fold, π. στιγμαί five sets of points, Arist. Metaph. 1076b32.
having five knots, Thphr. HP 1.8.3.
quincunx, Gloss.
five handbreadths wide, long, etc., X. Cyn. 9.14, 10.3 ; cf. πεντεπάλαστος.
five feet long, θριγκοί IG 7.3073.75 (Lebad.).
Thphr. HP 9.13.5, Dsc. 4.42.

definition: πενταπέτηλον, τό, = foreg., Nic. Th. 839, Androm. ap. Gal. 14.40.

children.definition: five cubits long or broad, Hdt. 9.83, Thphr. HP 9.4.2, PPetr. 3p.113 ( iii B. C., gen. -ους), LXX 1 Ch. 11.23, OGI 332.7 ( Elaea, ii B.C.) ; cf. πεντέπηχυς.
to be multiplied by five, interpol. in Nicom. Ar. 1.21.
five and 1/5 times as large :
five and 1/4 times :
five and 1/3 times :
five and 1/2 times ; all in Nicom. Ar. 1.22.

definition: πενταπλάσιος, α, ον, Ion. πεντα-πλήσιος, η, ον,

children.definition: five-fold, Hdt. 6.13, Arist. Pol. 1265b22 ; π. τινός five times as large as . . , ib. 1266b6 ; five times as much, Orib. Fr. 99. Adv. -ως LXX Ge. 43.34.
a being the fifth multiple, Nicom. Ar. 2.5.
J. AJ 12.2.8, Ael. NA 16.12, Heliod. in EN 98.25 ; πενταπλασίονα ἀποτεῖσαι to make five-fold restitution, Plu. VOrat. 2.846c.
five πλέθρα long, Hecat.Abd. ap. J. Ap. 1.22, (Max.Tyr. 8.6.
figure with five sides, Papp. 396.13, al.
five times twisted, Hp. ap. Paul.Aeg. 6.78 ( πεντάπλουν Hp. Fist. 4).

definition: πενταπλόος, α, ον, contr. πεντα-πλοῦς, ῆ, οῦν,

children.definition: five-fold, PRev.Laws 11.6, al. (iii B. C.), LXX 3 Ki. 6.31 ; ἡ πενταπλόα (sc. κύλιξ) a cup of five ingredients, Philoch. 43, Aristodem. ap. Ath. 11.495f.
Hp. Fist. 4.
league of five cities, Hdt. 1.144, LXX Wi. 10.6, Str. 6.2.4, POsl. 1.300 : metaph., of the five senses, Ph. 2.22.
with five passages, D.P. 301.
board of the first five men, Lat. quinqueprimi, Cod.Just. 12.28.2.1.
with five cases, Priscian. Inst. 5.76.
with five gates : τὰ Π., a quarter of Syracuse, Plu. Dio 29.
holder of five ἄρουραι, PPetr. 3p.243 (iii B.C.).
consisting of five staves or lines, Telest. 4 (dub. l.).

children.label: II
children.definition: [στρατηγὸς] π., = Lat. praetor quinquefascalis, IGRom. 1.971 ( Gortyn).
with five berries, AP 6.300 ( Leon.) ap. Suid. ( -ρρωγος cod. Pal.).
contribution of five ἀρτάβαι, POxy. 1445.3 (ii A.D.).
of five ἀρτάβαι, POxy. 1760.8 (ii A.D.).
magistracy of the Five, at Carthage, Arist. Pol. 1273a13.
group of five, Ascl. Tact. 7.6, Str. 15.1.51 (pl.) ; the number five, Arist. Metaph. 1082a2, Ph. 1.14, Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.264a, Iamb. Comm.Math. 18.
Quint. Inst. 9.4.51, Aristid. Quint. 1.14.
with five sets of tholes ( σκαλμοί), Ephipp. 5.17.
five spans long, broad, or high, X. Cyn. 2.4, 7, Str. 15.1.57 ; ἀνδριαντίδιον BCH 54.97 ( Delos, ii B.C.).

definition: πεντασταδιαῖος, α, ον, = sq., Luc. VH 1.40.

children.definition: of five stades, πορθμός, σκιά, Str. 7.6.1, 15.1.21 : -στάδιον, τό, distance of five stades, Id. 7.6.2.
five στατῆρες in weight, Sosicr. 1 codd. Poll.
of five lines or verses, AP 9.173 ( Pall.).
five-rowed, κριθή Thphr. HP 8.4.2.
with five mouths or openings, of the Nile, Hdt. 2.10 ; of the Ister, Id. 4.47 ; of the Rhone, Str. 4.1.8.
having five syllables, Eust. ad D.P. 916.
in five syllables, Eust. ad D.P. 431.

definition: πεντασύριγγος, v.l. for πεντεσ- in Poll. 8.72.

children.definition: of five different forms, Ps.-Plu. Metr. 3.
five σχοῖνοι long : -σχοινον, = στάδιον, Hsch.
the Pentateuch, Isid. Etym. 6.2.1,2, Gloss.
consisting of five drugs or ingredients : pentapharmacum, Hist. Aug. Hel. 5 [Ael.?].
of five-fold nature : five, ὄνυχες AP 7.383 ( Phil.).
divided into five watches, νύξ Stesich. 55 ( πεντε- codd.).
five-fold order of priests in Egypt, OGI 111.20 ( ii B.C., prob. rest.), BGU 149.6 (ii/iii A.D.), etc.
five-petalled, Thphr. HP 6.6.4 :
cinquefoil, Potentilla reptans, Hp. Morb. 2.42, Thphr. HP 9.13.5, Gal. 12.96 ; also Potentilla argentea, Hp. Ulc. 20 :—written πεντέφυλλον Dsc. 4.42, but πεντάφ- Id. 1 Prooem.
five-fold, in five divisions, Il. 12.87 ; but πεντάχα· ἡ χείρ, Hsch.
Arist. HA 526b8, Str. 16.4.25, Ph. 1.79, Plu. Def.orac. 2.429e.
five thousand, Tz. H. 7.96.
containing five χοίνικες, Poll. 4.168.
holding five χόες, κεράμια PMagd. 26 (iii B.C.).
five-stringed, [ μάγαδις] Ath. 14.637a : -χορδον, τό, a five-stringed instrument, Poll. 4.60 ; π. συστήματα scales of five notes, Theo Sm. p.49 H.
in five places, Hdt. 3.117.
consisting of five time-units, ῥυθμός D.H. Comp. 25 ; πούς Heph. 3.2.
in five ways, Theo Sm. p.23 H., S.E. M. 1.122, Eust. 32.40.

definition: πέντε, Aeol. πέμπε (q.v.), οἱ, αἱ, τά, indecl. (declined in Aeol.),

children.definition: five, Il. 10.317, etc. ; τὰ πέντε κρατήσας having won the πένταθλον, Simon. 155.11. (I.-E. penqṷe, cf. Skt. páñca, Lith. penki, etc. ‘five’.)
of five steps, κλῖμαξ J. BJ 5.5.2.
with five wards, κλειδίον IG 2(2).1533.27 (iv B.C.).
consisting of five lines, πεσσὰ π. draughts played on a board with five lines, S. Fr. 429 ; cf. πεντάγραμμον.
measuring five finger-breadths, ἐμπόλια π. πανταχῇ IG 2(2).1675.8.
sum of five δραχμαί, X. HG 1.6.12, Din. 1.56 ; coin worth five δραχμαί, cj. in Polyaen. 3.10.14.
at the price of five δραχμαί, μεδίμνους πυρῶν π. IG 2(2).360.9 ; σῖτος π. at the price of five δραχμαί per μέδιμνος, ib. 30.
fifteen, Simon. 125, Th. 3.94, Pl. R. 540a, etc. ; οἱ π. ἄνδρες, quindecimviri sacris faciundis, D.C. 53.1, cf. 42.51 ; ἱερεῖς οἱ π. καλούμενοι Id. 44.15.
figure with fifteen angles, Hero Deff. 138.11, Theo Sm. p.151 H., Procl. Hyp. 3.28.
term of fifteen years, Sch. Th. 1.18 : as Adj., π. περιφορά fifteen-year cycle, Men. Prot. p.49 D.
fifteen years old, Arist. HA 546a14, dub. in Plu. Cons.Apoll. 2.113d.
of or for fifteen years, ἀνοχαί D.H. 4.85.
fifteen times, Sch. Ptol. Geog. 1.24.2, Theo Sm. p.203 H.
weighing fifteen minae, Ph. Bel. 51.37.
squadron of fifteen ships, D. 14.18.

definition: πεντεκαιδέκανδρος, ὁ, ἱερεὺς π. ἐπὶ τῶν ἱεροποιῶν, =

children.definition: XV vir sacris faciundis, IGRom. 3.172.14 ( Ancyra) ; but π. τῶν ἐκδικαζόντων τὰ πράγματα wrongly used for decemvir stlitibus iudicandis, ib. 5.
fifteen cubits long or broad, Arist. Mir. 838a21 ; ξύλα Inscr.Délos 370.34 (iii B. C.) ; δᾷδες D.S. 17.115 :—also πεντεκαιδεκα-πηχυαῖος, α, ον, Tz. H. 1.813.

definition: πεντεκαιδεκαπλάσιος [πλᾰ], ον, = sq. (which is v.l.), Placit. 2.30.1.

children.definition: fifteen-fold, Ath. 2.57f.
on the fifteenth day, Str. 15.2.10, 16.4.23 ; π. τύπος πυρετοῦ Gal. 7.500.
worth fifteen talents, οἶκοι D. 28.11.
fifteenth part, Hp. Oct. 13.
fifteenth, Arist. Pr. 941b14, D.S. 12.81, Ev.Luc. 3.1 ; π. τόκοι Supp.Epigr. 4.664.17 ( Ilium, i B. C.).
with fifteen strings, Adrast. ap. Theon. Sm. p.64 H., Ptol. Harm. 3.1 tit., Porph. in Harm. p.168 D.
with fifteen banks of oars, Plu. Demetr. 20.
of fifteen days, ἀνοχαί Plb. 18.34.5.
of twenty-five time-units, Aristid. Quint. 1.14.
twenty-five, better divisim πέντε καὶ εἴκοσι.
twenty-five years old, D.C. 52.20.
twenty-fifth, Pl. Tht. 175b.
fifty-five years old, Pl. R. 460e.
in forty-five days, ὑγιέες γίνονται π. Hp. Nat.Hom. 12.
forty-five, Iamb. in Nic. p.16 P.
of thirty-five metres, Sch. Ar. Pax 974.
thirty-five years old, Pl. Lg. 774a.

definition: πεντέκλινον, τό, Att. for πεντάκλινον, Moer. p.321P.

children.definition: of five worlds, Dam. Pr. 124 bis.
with five purple threads woven zig-zag round the border, Antiph. 297, Men. 92, cf. Poll. 7.52 :—also πεντε-κτενής, ές, Hsch.
the five stones : πεντελίθοις παίζειν, a game played by women, in which five pebbles, potsherds, dice, etc., were tossed from the back of the hand and caught in the palm, jackstones, Ar. Fr. 366.
play πεντελίθοις (cf. foreg.), Hermipp. 34.
remaining out of five, last of five, Cic. Att. 14.21.4, 15.2.4.

definition: πεντέμηνον, τό, Att. for πεντάμηνον, Moer. p.321P.

children.definition: of fifty thousand medimni burden, Tz. H. 2.108.
of five sanctuaries, Dam. Pr. 124 bis.
lasting five years, σιγή Tz. H. 8.280.

definition: πεντέπηχυς, υ, Att. for πεντάπηχυς, Ael.Dion. Fr. 153.
πεντεπικαιδέκατος, η, ον, poet. for πεντεκαιδέκατος, AP 9.482.18 ( Agath.).

children.definition: of five feet, five feet long, IG 1(2).372.128, al., 2(2).1668.44, Pl. Tht. 147d :—later πεντάπους, Milet. 7.57 ( Didyma, iii/ii B. C.) ; ἄγαλμα Arr. Peripl.M.Eux. 3 ; πεντάπους τὸ ὄρυγμα, = carrecta, Gloss.

children.definition: weighing five talents, βάρος Simp. in Ph. 1104.10 (v.l. πεντατάλαντος).
happening every five years, quinquennial, Str. 7.7.6, D.C. 51.1 ; cf. πενθετηρικός.
term of five years, διὰ πεντετηρίδος every fifth year (inclusively), Hdt. 3.97, 4.94.

children.label: II
children.definition: festival celebrated every fifth year (inclusively), Id. 6.111, Th. 3.104, IG 1(2).84.6, 32, 2(2).1172.27.

five years old, ἐλέφας Arist. HA 546b8, cf. IG 3.1307, etc.
to be conquered five times, AP 11.84 ( Lucill.).
piece of five χαλκοῖ, Aristopho 2.
holding five χόες, ὑδρία Ar. Fr. 136.
space of five years, Sch. Ar. Pl. 584.
of fifty days, προθεσμία D.H. 2.57.
fifty, Il. 2.509, etc. : Boeot. πεντείκοντα Corinn. Supp. 2.67 : gen. pl. πεντηκόντων Schwyzer 688 D 7 (Chios, V B.C.).
worth fifty drachmae, Pl. Cra. 384b.
weighing fifty drachmae, IG 7.3498.26 (Orop.).

children.definition: πεντηκοντάδραχμον, τό, gold coin nominally worth fifty silver drachmae, PCair.Zen. 22 (iii B. C.) ; at Cyrene, Poll. 9.60.
fifty-six, LXX 1 Es. 5.10, al.
period of fifty years, Sch. Th. 1.18.
fifty years old, Pl. Alc. 1.127e, D.H. 4.29, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: of or lasting fifty years, χρόνος D.S. 4.58, etc. : fem., πεντηκονταέτιδες σπονδαί Th. 5.32 codd. (leg. -ούτ-).
the age of fifty years, D.H. 4.32, Ph. 1.551.

children.definition: period of fifty years, ib. 532, Sch. Th. 1.97.
of fifty-three years, χρόνος Plb. 3.4.2.
fifty-headed, Hes. Th. 312 ( -κέφᾱλον (sic) codd.).

definition: πεντηκοντακέφαλος, ον, = foreg., Simon. 203, f. l. in Pi. Fr. 93 ( ἑκατοντακάρανον cj. Herm.) ; cited from Hes. (v. foreg.) by Sch. S. Tr. 1098.

weighing fifty minae, Ph. Bel. 51.40.

fifty cubits high. Callix. 2, J. BJ 5.5.8.
fifty plethra large, Eust. 776.60 : poet. πεντηκοντα-πέλεθρος, Nonn. D. 25.504.
to be πεντηκόνταρχος, D. 50.25.
his office, Pl. Lg. 707a.

children.label: II
children.definition: company of sixty-four light-armed men, Ascl. Tact. 6.3, Arr. Tact. 14.3, Ael. Tact. 16.1 : pl., Onos. 34.2.

leader of a company of fifty, LXX Ex. 18.21, 4 Ki. 1.9.

children.label: II
children.definition: the number fifty, Ph. 2.481.
matter of fifty staters, Leg.Gort. 2.38.
fifty talents, D. ap. Poll. 9.52.
fifty-four, LXX 2 Es. 2.7.
fifty-three, LXX Ge. 5.31.

ship with fifty oars, Pi. P. 4.245, IG 1(2).23, Hdt. 1.152, al., Th. 1.14 ; πεντηκόντ-ορος is v.l. in Pi. l.c., Hdt. 6.138, Th. l.c., and is found in E. IT 1124 (lyr.), Marm.Par. 15.
commander of fifty men, name of an officer in the Spartan army, Th. 5.66, X. An. 3.4.21 :—written πεντηκοστήρ in Id. Lac. 11.4, 13.4, HG 3.5.22, 4.5.7.
Polyaen. 4.11.3.
of fifty acres of corn land, Il. 9.579, Pherecyd. 30 J.
with fifty stories, Hsch. ( -ολμον cod.).
fifty fathoms deep or high, Hdt. 2.149.

definition: πεντηκοντόστολον ὅπου οἱ δραπέται ἀνάγονται, Hsch.

children.definition: fifty years old, Pl. R. 540a, Lg. 670b.

children.label: II

definition: πεντηκόσιοι, αι, α, Ep. for πεντᾰκόσιοι,

on the fiftieth day, Gal. 7.478.
chairman of the company which farmed the πεντηκοστή, AB 297, Phot. ( -οντ- cod.).
to be charged with a tax of two per cent. on any articles, D. 35.29 ; also of the articles, to have the tax paid upon them, οὐδʼ ὁτιοῦν εὑρίσκομεν . . πεπεντηκοστευμένον ib. 30.

collect the πεντηκοστή, Philonid. 5 ap. Poll. 9.27.
office of πεντηκοστολόγοι, IG 11 (2). 154 A 38 ( Delos, iii B. C.), Anon. ap. Suid.
collector of the πεντηκοστή, at Athens, D. 21.133, 34.7, Eub. 122 ; at Delos, SIG 975.10 (iii B. C.) ; at Cyparissia, ib. 952.9 (iv/iii B. C.).
fifty-first, Hero Geom. 15.10, al.
fiftieth, Pl. Tht. 175b.

children.label: II

μερίς), fiftieth part : hence, tax of two per cent. on exports and imports, at Athens, And. 1.133, D. 59.27 : pl., Id. 24.120 ; ἐς Ἀθάνας πεντηκοστὰ τῶν λίθων IG 4(2)(1).103.46 (Epid.) ; at Delos, ib. 2(2).1635.38 (iv B. C.), 11(2).161 A 26 (iii B. C.) ; at Halicarnassus, OGI 46.12 (iii B. C.) ; τῶν πρηθέντων τελείτω π. SIG 229.5 ( Erythrae, iv B. C.) ; = Lat. quinquagesima, D.C. 55.31 (s. v. l.) : metaph., ταύτην εὕρηκε Μειδίας καινὴν ἱππικήν τινα πεντηκοστήν invented a new sort of composition of two per cent. in lieu of his cavalry service, i. e. paid this instead of it, D. 21.166.
ἡμέρα), fiftieth day (after the Passover), Pentecost, LXX 2 Ma. 12.32 ; ἡ ἡμέρα τῆς Π. Act.Ap. 2.1.
body of fifty, as a division of the Spartan army, Th. 5.68 ; κατὰ πεντηκοστῦς (acc. pl.) X. An. 3.4.22.
farmer of the πεντηκοστή, prob. in AB 297 (pl.), cf. Ostr. 43 (i A. D.), Theb.Ostr. 130 (ii A. D.).
quinquereme, Plb. 8.4.2, al. (but f.l. for πεντετηρίς Hdt. 6.87) ; in full, ναῦς π. D.S. 2.5, 14.41 : πεντηρικὰ πλοῖα, σκάφη, Plb. 1.59.8, 3.41.2, cf. D.S. 14.41.
with five branches : as Subst., of the human hand, Hes. Op. 742, Hsch. s.v. ἐμῇ πεντόζῳ (prob.).
of five fathoms, AP 11.87 ( Lucill.) ; cf. πεντώρυγος.
oath by five gods, IG 9(1).333.16 ( Locr., v B. C.).
IG 11(2).161 B 19 ( Delos, iii B. C.) : πεντώροβος, BCH 32.11 (ibid., iv B. C.), IG 2(2).1451.29, 1452.7.

of or worth five obols, π. ἡλιάσασθαι to sit in the Heliaea at five obols a day, Ar. Eq. 798 ; τόκος π. IG 11(2).146 B 17 ( Delos, iv/iii B. C.) ; δραχμᾶν δύο πεντωβόλου ib. 42(1).109 ii 123 (Epid.) ; κυλίκιον τοῦ πεντωβόλου a cup of five-obol wine, Lyc. Fr. 2.2.
Epich. 9.

definition: πεντῳδουμένη μονάς, = 10,000, Iamb. in Nic. p.89 P. (Fort. πεντοδ-.)

definition: πεπάγουσα ἁπαλή, Hsch. πεπᾰθυῖα, v. πάσχω.

definition: πεπαίνω, aor. ἐπέπᾱνα (v. infr. 2) :— Pass., fut. πεπανθήσομαι : aor. ἐπεπάνθην (v. infr.) : pf. inf. πεπάνθαι Arist. Pr. 925a13 : ( πέπων) :—

children.definition: ripen, Hdt. 1.193 ; ὀρχάτους ὀπωρινούς E. Fr. 896 ; π. τὴν ὀπώραν, of the vine, bring its fruit to maturity or perfection, X. Oec. 19.19, cf. Arist. Mir. 846b1 ; [ ἡ συκῆ] π. τέτταρας καρπούς Thphr. HP 4.2.3; but [ συκῆ] π. τὴν σάρκα τοῦ ὄρνιθος, by being boiled with it, Plu. QConv. 2.697b : abs., διασκοπῶν ἥδομαι τὰς . . ἀμπέλους, εἰ πεπαίνουσιν ἤδη, i.e. if the grapes are ripening, Ar. Pax 1163 (lyr.) :— Pass., become ripe, Hdt. 4.199, Ion Trag. 57, Trag.Adesp. 396, Gp. 4.6.1, etc.

soften, assuage, πεπᾶναι ὀργήν Ar. V. 646 ; χρόνος ὁ πάντα πεπαίνειν εἰωθώς Plu. Cons.Apoll. 2.102a ; ὀργὴ πεπανθήσεται X. Cyr. 4.5.21 ; τὸ πεπανθὲν ἔρωτος τραῦμα AP 12.80 ( Mel.) ; of a person, ἢν πεπανθῇς E. Heracl. 159.

Pass., of tumours, soften and suppurate, Hp. Epid. 6.2.16 ; of illness generally, come to a head, mature, Id. Aph. 2.40, Prog. 12 ; μέχρι ἂν τῆς νούσου ἡ ἀκμὴ πεπανθῇ Id. Acut. 38 ; also οὖρα πεπαινόμενα Id. Epid. 1.3.

data.quote: μέχρι ἂν τῆς νούσου ἡ ἀκμὴ πεπανθῇ

children.definition: χρὼς ἐπὶ χρωτὶ πεπαίνετο grew warm, Theoc. 2.140.

definition: πέπανος, ον, rarer collat. form of πέπων, Artem. 1.73, 2.25, Porph. Gaur. 13.4 ;=

children.definition: maturus, mitis, passus, Gloss.; πεπανός· ὁ πολὺν χρόνον ἔχων παρὰ τὸ ὀπτηθῆναι, Hsch.: Comp. - ώτερος Paus. 9.19.8 : metaph., more experienced, Lyd. Mag. 3.10 ( Comp.). [Oxyt. in Artem. 2.25, Hsch.]
ripening, of fruits, Arist. Mete. 380a11, Thphr. HP 5.1.2, 3.4.1 (pl.), Corn. ND 30.
maturation, of tumours and the like, Arist. Mete. 380a21.
able to ripen or soften, c. gen., πτυάλου Hp. Acut. 66 ; π. δύναμις Dsc. 5.125 ; π. μέλος (of music) soothing strain, prob. cj. in Iamb. VP 25.113.

definition: πεπαρεῖν, aor. 2 inf., only in Pi. P. 2.57 (v.l. πεπορεῖν, also cited by Hsch., who expl. πεπαρεῖν by ἐνδεῖξαι, σημῆναι, display, manifest ; and cites πεπᾰρεύσιμος· εὔφραστος, σαφής).

children.definition: πεπάσμην, v. πατέομαι.
concoction of sputum or urine, Hp. Epid. 1.2, 3.10 (pl.); πεπασμοὶ σπέρματος Aret. CD 1.4.
suppuration, Hp. Epid. 3.4.

definition: πέπειρα, ἡ, rare fem. of πέπων (formed on analogy of πίειρα, fem. of πίων), used of women,

soft, pulpy, τὴν σάρκα πέπειραν ποιεῖ Hp. VC 11 ( v.l. - ον) : metaph., ὀργὴ π. S. Tr. 728.

ripe, of fruit, Thphr. CP 3.6.9 ( Comp.), LXX Ge. 40.10, AP 12.185 ( Strat.); of girls, opp. νέαι, v.l. in Ar. Ec. 896 ; παρθένοι Plu. Comp.Lyc.Num. 4, cf. Lyc. 15 ; φιλέουσι πέπειρος AP 12.9 ( Strat.).
mild, πεπειροτέρους γεγονότας D.H. 9.49.
π. νοῦσος a disease come to its crisis, Hp. Acut. 39 ; also πεπειρότερον πτύελον more concocted, Id. Epid. 2.3.4.
confidently, π. διεγγυώμενος D.L. 9.71, cf. 4.56 ; from conviction, Ptol. Alm. 2.6, Iamb. VP 30.175 : f.l. in Str. 15.1.24 ( ἀπεφεισμένως cj. Mein.).
a definite number of times, Arist. APo. 82b32.
peppered, Gp. 8.39 tit.: πεπερᾶτον, τό, wine flavoured with pepper, SIG 1171.10 ( Crete).

pepper, Piper nigrum, Antiph. 277, Arist. Po. 1458a15, Dsc. 2.159, etc.: gen. πεπέρεως Plu. Sull. 13, Ath. 9.381b ; πεπέριος Thphr. HP 9.20.2 : pl., τὰ τρία πεπέρια Orib. Fr. 67 : other forms imply nom. πέπερις, ὁ, gen. τοῦ πεπέριδος Eub. 128 ; dat. πεπέριδι Ael. NA 9.48 ; acc. πέπεριν Nic. Al. 332, Th. 876; gen. pl. πεπερίδων Ath. 9.376d: also fem., αἱ πεπέριδες pepper-trees, Philostr. VA 3.4.
π. πρόμηκες, μακρόν, long pepper, Piper officinarum, Thphr. HP 9.20.1, Dsc. 2.159. (Gen. sg. πιπέρεως Stud.Pal. 20.27.3 (ii/iii A. D.).)
taste like pepper, τῇ γεύσει Dsc. 2.160.
peppered γάρον, Alex.Trall. 1.15 (written πιπερό-).
peppered broth, Cyran. 109.
closely, Hsch. s.v. βύζην.
